Cross-examined. Q. Did you run away from your father? A. Yes, I did—I have told all the conversation that took place between the prisoner and me—I am sure I have forgotten nothing remarkable—he, told me he
had two silk handkerchiefs in his jacket pocket, and he placed them under the window—he said nothing else—I did not know that Jones had robbed his own father—I never swore that I did.

Q. Did not the Magistrate say he bailed him (the prisoner) because he had a doubt whether you were telling the truth or not, as you admitted you went away with a boy that robbed his own father, and you knew it? A. No—I never said to a gentleman that I went away with Jones, and I knew he robbed his father of 13s. 6d.—Jones was before the Magistrate.
RICHARD PIPPIN JONES . I was with the last witness and the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you and Fowler go away that night? A. Yes—I was suspected of robbing my father—I told that to Fowler, and he knew it when he went away with me—I was at Hatton-garden—I remem
ber Fowler being sworn there—he told the Magistrate there he went away with me, and that he knew I had robbed my father of 13s. 6d.

SAMUEL TAYLOR (police-constable N 167.) I was sent for to the prose
cutor's on the Sunday evening, and took the prisoner—I have the hand-kerchiefs.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not the prisoner taken first on a charge of embezzlement? A. Yes, by his master.

MR. PHILLIPS called DAVID LUDLOW. I live in Crawford-street. On Sunday, the 24th of March, the prosecutor called on me—he inquired about the prisoner's cha
racter—he did not say one word about his having a charge against him for stealing handkerchiefs—he told me at the office that he would get the pri
soner sent to Newgate, to prevent an action being brought; and that when he got him there he would try to get him off.

MR. DOANE. Q. I believe the prosecutor had a character of the prisoner from you? A. Yes, he had—when he came to me on the Sunday, be came to know whether I had any suspicion of the prisoner, and said he had robbed him of 13s. 6d.—my wife and my wife's mother were present—he did not say that as they had threatened to bring an action against him, be must go on with the prosecution—I said, "Has not he robbed you of any goods?"—he said, "No, I am sorry to say he has not, because the most distressing thing of all is, the boy, who he says, gave him the money, has gone away, and his parents are distressed, as he has not returned"—he said to me, at the police-office, "It may appear harsh to you to go on in this case, but, unless I get the boy convicted, I shall be liable to an action."
NOT GUILTY .

1387.
ELIZABATH MURPHY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of April, 1 tongue, value 8d., the goods of
Daniel Lucas.

DANIEL LUCAS . I live in Calmel-buildings, and am a grocer. About twelve o'clock on Saturday night, the 6th of April, the prisoner came to purchase some tea and sugar—she paid, and was about to leave the shop—she then said she had lost a thimble—my young man took the candle to go and look by the counter for it—I saw the prisoner take a tongue, and put it into her apron—I said, "What have you got in your apron?"—she said, nothing but what she had paid me for—I took down her apron, and found this tongue—she got outside—I called the officer, and gave her in charge.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you know her before? A. I had—she was not intoxicated.

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Nine Days.

1388.
HENRY EMERY was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 coat, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Thomas Danforth.

THOMAS DANFORTH . I live in Back-road, St. George's East The pri
soner lived in the same house, but not in the same room—I had a coat on the 30th of March—I missed it on the 31st, when I went to my box—this is it.—(looking at it)—I had a letter sent to me on Easter Monday, with the duplicate in it.
JAMES GILL . I am shopman to Mr. Fleming, a pawnbroker. I took in this coat of the prisoner, to the best of my belief.

THOMAS SQUIRE (police-constable K 182.) I took the prisoner—I told him it was for stealing a coat—he said, "You must prove it"—I said, "It is pawned in the name of Smith"—he said, "Smith knows nothing about it; Green took it, and I pawned it"—I said, "The prosecutor has re
ceived a letter with the duplicate, is it your writing?"—he said, "Yes, I sent it."

Prisoner's Defence. I took the coat as a pattern round to the trade—Green went with me—I stood outside, while he took it into shops, and then he went away with it—the letter I never wrote nor sent—I never pawned the coat.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Two Months.

1389.
AMELIA READER was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 counterpane, value 3s., and 1 pair of stays, value 3s., the goods of
John Reader: and that she had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN READER . I live in Princes-street, Tyson-street, Bethnal-green—I left home on the 9th of April, about ten o'clock in the morning, and left my daughter (the prisoner) in possession of my house—at eleven o'clock in the evening I came home, and missed ray counterpane off my bed, and the following day I missed the stays—the prisoner came home, I told her I had missed them—she acknowledged taking them, and said she had pledged them—I have no wife, I have three other small children—the prisoner is the eldest—she said she wished to be transported for seven years.
WILLIAM GOLDER . I am a pawnbroker. I produce the counterpane and stays, which I took in of the prisoner.

Prisoner. I am very sorry for what I have done—I will not do so any more—it is through my sister, who turned me out of doors—my father has more need to correct his other children than me—he has said he wished to transport me—I want to go home to work to earn money.
CHARLES BYRON (police-constable H 157.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person who was tried.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years,—Penitentiary.

1390.
BENJAMIN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 1 jacket, value 4s., the goods of
George Webster.

GEORGE WEBSTER . I am servant to Mr. Malcolm, a surgeon in Rat
cliffe-highway—I had a jacket on the 7th of April, hanging by the parlour-door—I missed it about nine o'clock—this is it.
GEORGE MALCOLM . I am a surgeon in Ratcliffe-highway—about half-past nine o'clock that evening, I saw the prisoner coming out of my passage,

where this jacket was—I asked him what he wanted, he said "A penny worth of liquorice-pipe"—I saw he had this jacket under his arm—he told me his brother bad picked it up across the street, and had given it to him but it had been hanging up in my house—I saw another boy standing at my door when I went in.
PATRICK HORAN (police-constable H 176.) I received the prisoner in charge.

Prisoner's Defence. My brother gave me the jacket—I went into the shop, and the gentleman took me—I said I would get my brother, I went out three yards, and then came back with the jacket under my arm.
MR. MALCOLM re-examined. He did not leave the house at all.

GUILTY. Aged 13.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Ten Days, and
Whipped.

1391.
RACHEL HACKET and
WILLIAM GLADMAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April, 6 sovereigns, the monies of
William Richmond, from his person.

WILLIAM RICHMOND . I am a brick-maker, residing at North Hyde, in Middlesex—on the 8th of April, between nine and ten o'clock, I was at a public-house at Hanwell—the two prisoners were there and another per
son with them—I went in to have a pint of beer—I had taken a £10 note from home and changed it—I had seven sovereigns with me and some silver—Hacket forced herself into my company—she came and sat along-side of me, and put her hand into my breeches—she said she would have it, whether or nay—I said, "Keep off, I don't want any thing of the kind"—we had a drop of beer together—I cannot say that I was exactly sober—I was rather fresh—I know she pulled me and mauled me about a good deal—after that, I put my hand into my pocket, and missed six sovereigns besides some silver—no other person could have taken it—she and the two men were gone then.

Hacket. Q. Did you not send me for some snuff, and give me some money? A. No; not a halfpenny—when I paid for a pint of beer, she saw the sovereigns in my hand, and she wanted to pick a few halfpence out from among them.

CHARLES SWEETMAN . I live at the public-house. The two prisoners came there together—the prosecutor sat opposite to Gladman, and Hacket sat by his side—I saw her take very great liberties with him, and her hand was either in his small-clothes or his pocket—I suppose the pri
soners went out first, but I did not see them go—the prosecutor did not state his loss that night—I did not hear he had been robbed till the next morning—he staid at our house waiting for the arrival of his wife—he went home with his wife—he paid for what he had.

ROBERT RICHMOND . I am the prosecutor's son. He told me of his loss—on the Tuesday morning I went to Hanwell, and saw Gladman and an old man drinking with him—the men were pointing to Gladman about a pair of new shoes he had on, and a smock frock—he put up his leg, and said, "I should not have had them, if she had not worked hard last night for them."

JAMES CUISHEN (police-constable T 135.) I received information of this on the Tuesday, and about an hour afterwards I saw the two prisoners in a public-house in New Brentford—I called Hacket out, and told her I must take her, for robbing a man of seven sovereigns and a purse—she

said she knew nothing about it, she had not been with any man at all—I then called Gladman out—he said he knew nothing of it—in going along I asked Hacket if she had been to, the pawnbroker's—the said the had not—I then asked Gladman how he came by the new boots and the smock-frock—he said he bought them with money that she (Hacket) had given him.
JOHM WILLIAM JENNINGS . I am a pawnbroker, and live at Brentford. On that Tuesday morning Hacket came and redeemed two pledges for 12s.—she bought a gown for 8s., and gave me a sovereign.

Hacket. The prosecutor went out with me, and gave me some money, and the next morning I asked this prisoner, who is my brother, to accompany me to Brentford—the prosecutor told the Magistrate he had 800l. in his pocket.

WILLIAM RICHMOND
re-examined. I went home to bed at ten o'clock—I had better than 1100l. in my side pocket, in bills.

HACKET—
GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.

GLADMAN—
NOT GUILTY .

1392.
WILLIAM MAYBIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 purse, value 2d.; 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 4 pence, and 6 half
pence; the goods and monies of
John Day, from the person of,
Hannah Day.

HANNAH DAY . I am the wife of George Day, of Denmark-street, St. George's-in-the-East. About ten o'clock in the evening of the 9th of April, I was standing at a picture shop—I saw a little boy by my side, and a boy behind me—I had a little child with me—I lifted her up to show her the pictures—I had 5s. and a penny in all in my pocket—I had one half-crown and 2s.—I felt my pocket robbed, and I heard the other boy say to the prisoner, "Come on, it is all right"—there were others about, but no one could have taken my money but those two—they both ran off together—I ran, till I fell down, and could not run any further—this is my purse and money—(looking at them.)

DANIEL BURGESS . I saw the prisoner going along the street, and the prosecutrix running after him, calling, "Stop thief"—I stopped him—he said, "I have got nothing," and as soon as he made use of those words he dropped some coppers down an area—I did not see the purse found—I took the prisoner to the station-house.

HONOBA CARTHY . I saw two boys running, and the prosecutrix was crying, "Stop thief"—Burgess stopped one of the boys, and at that time one of them threw this purse down—I ran and took it up, and gave it to the policeman.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a boy and a woman running, calling, "Stop thief"—I did not throw any coppers away.
(The prisoner received a. good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month; the last Week Solitary.

1393.
ELIZA SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of April, 1 pair of pattens, value 1s., the goods of
William Adams.

WILLIAM ADAMS . I am a pawnbroker, and live in High-street, Shore
ditch. On the 6th of April the prisoner came to transact some business, about half-past seven o'clock, and as she left the shop she stooped down,

put her hand under a table, and took a pair of pattens from a lot—I fol
lowed, and brought her back.
LAMBERT WILKINSON (police-constable G 175.) I took the prisoner and have the pattens.
Prisoner. A person with me took them, and gave them to me.

WILLIAM ADAMS
re-examined. There was a woman with her, who walked before her, and as the prisoner followed her she stooped and took them.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1394.
MARY M'GILL was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 10 handkerchiefs, value 2l., the goods of
William Dalton, her master.

WILLIAM DALTON . I live in Harper-street, Chelsea. The prisoner worked for me on the 5th of April—I heard from Lady Ross and others that their things were not right—I then went to the pawnbroker's, and found four handkerchiefs—I got an officer—I went to the prisoner's house, and gave her in charge—these handkerchiefs are mine—they belonged to my customers—I had them to wash.
GEORGE BROOKS . I am a pawnbroker. I produce seven handkerchiefs which I took in of a woman at different times, in the name of Ann Clarkson—these are the duplicates I gave—I do not know the woman.

HENRY KIMBER (police-sergeant V 20.) I went to the prisoner—she said she knew nothing about them—I said I was going to take her to the station-house—she asked me to allow her to put on another gown—she then said if the prosecutor would allow, her time she would take them out.

WILLIAM DALTON
re-examined. The man the prisoner lives with, said in her presence, that her name was Clarkson, but she always worked for me in the name of M'Gill.
Prisoner. I did not pledge all the handkerchiefs—I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Year.

1395.
JAMES HOLSTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 2 yards of woollen cloth, value 2l. 2s., the goods of
Vincent Daniels.

VINCENT DANIELS . I live in Brewer-street, and am a woollen draper. On the 9th of April, the prisoner came in with two patterns of silk, and asked if I could match them—I said I could not—he then untied a piece of, cloth, and asked if I could match that—I said I could not—he asked me to show him the nearest I had, and while I was getting that, there was a remnant of cloth on the counter, which he tied up—he said the cloth I showed him was not near enough, and was going out—when he got to the door, I asked him to walk in again—he came in and said, "For God's sake Mr. Daniels don't do it, I will give you it back."

Prisoner. Q. Do you state that I took the cloth, tied it in my hand-kerchief, and went to the door? A. Yes, I collared you at the door—a young man came to the door, and I sent him for the policeman—the pri
soner said, "No, I will pay Mr. Daniels for it"—he ran behind the counter, untied the cloth and his own garment, threw it under the counter, and said, "What have I got of yours?"—he had no money about him, only a flash note—when the policeman came, he was in the middle of the shop—I had hold of his arm—he had got out of the house when I took him back—when the policeman came I fetched this piece of, cloth from
under the counter—I did not select it from a number of pieces on the counter.

COURT. Q. Do you swear that he tied it up in his handkerchief, and took it out of the door? A. Yes, he got down three steps—he tied up his little coat first, then opened one corner, and tied up this cloth.

JOHN MURCH (police-constable C 106.) I was sent for—when I got to the shop, the prosecutor was holding the prisoner by the arm—he said he had taken a piece of cloth—Mr. Daniels went behind the counter and picked up the cloth—I searched the prisoner at the station-house, and found no money on him, but a pocket-book, and a flash note.
Prisoner. I said I had a half-sovereign and a half-crown. Witness. No, you did not.

Prisoner's Defence. I had a little portion of a tunic coat in the bundle, and I wanted to make a pair of towsers to match it for my own child, and to match some waistcoats—he said he had not got it—my little coat was then lying on the pieces of cloth. I took the coat and tied it up in my bundle—he was looking at me all the time—it is not likely I should take any thing else—I had not stepped beyond the threshold of the door—he took me and told a young man to fetch a policeman—I said, "For what?"—he said. "If you don't know what is your own, I will tell you"—I said, "I have nothing but what I paid for"—I did not say, "I will pay you"—he se
lected this from a quantity of pieces, and I said, "If you are so inclined, why not take the first piece that comes to hand?"—that note was put into my hand one day in the street.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1396.
WILLIAM HODGES was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of March, 1 saddle, value 5s., the goods of
Moses Jacobs, his master.

STEPHEN SLAUGHTER . I am in the employ of Moses Jacobs, a glass-merchant, in Berwick-street, Oxford-street. The prisoner was occasionally employed as a labourer—my master rents some premises in Rupert-street, where the horse and cart are usually put up—on the 16th of March, the prisoner was employed to move the cart and some harness from one stable to another, in Rupert-street, Haymarket—I saw a gig saddle and other things safe in the stable, between six and seven o'clock, when I went to do up my horse—I went there again the next morning, and they were gone—on the 22nd I came through Smithfield, and saw a lad with my master's saddle for sale—I knew it, and gave the lad into custody—this is the saddle—I never authorised any body to take it.
Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What name is over Mr. Jacobs' door? A. Jacobs only—his son's name David Jacobs, it is on the cart, but it is his father's business.

DANIEL SUTHERWOOD . I am a costermonger. I bought this saddle of the prisoner on Saturday night, three or four weeks back, for 1s. 6d.—I sent it to Smithfield on the Friday following, to be sold by a boy—it would not fit my donkey—it has been a pony-saddle—he said he had a collar and harness to sell.
Cross-examined. Q. Is the boy here? A. No—I know it is the saddle I bought—I gave it to a boy named Johnny—he works for me.

THOMAS WELLS (police-sergeant C 1.) I took the prisoner into custody on the 4th of April, at a house in Hopton-street, where he was wakeing a dead body—I had been trying to find him for several days—I asked if he knew Mr. Jacobs wanted him for stealing some harness—he said he did, but he was advised to keep out of the way.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say his master's son advised him to keep out? A. He might—he said at the office that the son gave it him.
DAVID JACOBS . I am the son of Moses Jacobs. I never gave this saddle or any harness to the prisoner—I never authorised him to take it from the stable.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it your saddle? A. No—the cart is not mine—my name is on it, but it was bought with my father's money—my fa
ther's name is on the shop, not David—the name over the door is Jacobs—the horse which this harness was bought for, was sold, but when we bought another horse, we put this saddle on it—I do not know what chucking things to blazes means—I have not been attacked by my father for giving these things away—I never sent the prisoner a message—I did not know where he was to be found.

MOSES JACOBS . I keep a glass-shop in Berwick-street. I have been a housekeeper twenty-five years—I did not authorise the prisoner or any one to take away this harness or saddle—it belonged to me, only the name of Jacobs is over the door—I never charged a man with giving away these things.
NOT GUILTY .

1397.
GEORGE THOMSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of April, 1 shawl, value 3s., the goods of
Ellen Paine, from her person.

ELLEN PAINE . On the 12th of April I met the prisoner and another young man in a public-house in North-street, Knightsbridge—I had two shawls on—I missed one in a house which the prisoner and another man, named Butcher, brought me to—they were strangers to me—I am an un
fortunate girl—I had the shawl loose on me, and as the prisoner was going out of the room, he took it, and put the light out as he was going out—I said to the other young man that I had missed my shawl—he said it must be about the room—he got a light and looked about the room, and it was not to be found—Butcher and I came out of the house—I gave Butcher in charge as I came out, and he told where Thomson lived—this is my shawl—(looking at it.)

WILLIAM WARDLOW (police-constable B 87.) The prosecutrix accused Butcher of stealing the shawl—I took him to the station-house—he then said it was the other person—that his name was Thomson, and directed me where to go—I went to No. 12, Kingston-street, Pimlico, and found the prisoner and the shawl—he said he knew nothing about it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe the prisoner opened the door? A. Yes.
— BUTCHER. I was with the prisoner's brother last Thursday night at the public-house, and with the prosecutrix.

JOSEPH THOMPSON . On Thursday night I was at a public-house with Butcher—I went to a house with the prosecutrix—I had a travelling shawl about my neck—I was rather tipsy—I put the shawl into my pocket—the

lights were put out when I got up from the bed, and felt for the shawl, I found a shawl, and put it round my neck, and went home—I was at home when the policeman came to my house—they took my brother, the prisoner—my mother let me in that night—the policeman came to the door to me while I was throwing some dirt up at the windows, and spoke to me—he had an opportunity of seeing me.

HANNAH THOMSON . On Thursday night I let my son Joseph into my house—he appeared to me to be tipsy—he stumbled on the stain—I helped him up—I did not observe whether he had a shawl on—our door is dark, having an arch-way over it—my son George, the prisoner, was in bed at eleven o'clock that night.
GEORGE LARKIN (police-constable B 65.) I remember on Friday morning seeing Joseph Thomson throw dirt up at the window—I went to him and told him to be careful not to break the windows.
NOT GUILTY .

1398.
ELIZA M'CARTHY was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 7 yards of calico, value 4s.; 2 shirts, value 1s. 6d.; 1 gown, value 3s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 5s. 6d.; 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 table-cloth, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1l.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 12s.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 1s.; and a two-penny piece; the goods and monies of
Samuel Blain.

CHARLOTTE BLAIN . I am the wife of Samuel Blain, we lodge in a first-floor in Devonshire-street, at a coffee-shop—the prisoner used fre
quently to come there of a morning for about ten minutes, to have her coffee—she was there on the afternoon of the 3rd of April—I saw her go into the yard—I was in the back parlour—my room door was shut when I left it, but not locked—my property was safe—I was absent about an hour and a half, and when I returned I found the room stripped of all the property—the two-penny piece had been in a little box in the drawer that the clothes were taken out of—it was a two-penny copper-piece—I saw the prisoner again the same evening at the station-house, about two hours after I lost my property—I have lost all my property except the two-penny piece—it was not locked in the drawer, but the little box was—I had seen her at the shop that evening.
WILLIAM FINCH . I can swear to this two-penny piece by the marks on it—I had sold it to Samuel Blain nine or ten months ago—I am certain it is the same.

THOMAS HENRY THOMSON (police-sergeant P 4.) I took the prisoner—she denied being in Devonshire-street at all or at the coffee-shop—I asked if she did not know a shop there—she said, "No," and she had not been there—I found this two-penny piece on her, 17s. in silver, 31/2d. in copper, a token, and four keys, one of which opens the private door of the house the prosecutor lodges in.
ELIZABETH SPREADBOROUGH . I searched the prisoner, and found this property on her.

CHARLOTTE BLAIN
re-examined. This is the two-penny piece my hus
band had and lost.
SAMUEL BLAIN . I bought this two-penny piece of Finch—I believe this to be the same—it was in this box—it was broken open and the Piece taken out.
Prisoner's Defence. The two-penny piece was my own, and the money too.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

1399.
JOHN THOMSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of March, 1 shovel, value 2s., the goods of
William Butcher.

WILLIAM BUTCHER . About the 1st of March, I was at work at Mr. Hutchings's, at Kensington, in the garden—I left my shovel in Mr. Hutch
ings's shed—I did not see it again till the 6th of April—the prisoner was at work there.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know it? A. There are some letters on the handle which I can see plainly.

JOHN SLAUGHTER . I went into Mr. Taylor's, opposite Mr. Hutchings's, a fortnight ago last Wednesday—I asked the prisoner if he knew any body that could lend me a shovel—he said, "I have got one—I gave 1s. and a pot of beer for"—I said, "I will give you 1s. and a pint of beer for it"—I gave him 6d., and the next night he brought it openly before the people, and I paid him.
NOT GUILTY .

1400.
MARY WATSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 decanter, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Frederick Hardy.

FREDERICK HARDT . I live in York-street, Westminster, and am an earthenware dealer. On the 8th of April I saw the prisoner come between eight and nine feet from the pavement into the shop, which has an open front—she took this decanter, put it under her shawl, and walked away—I went and took it from her two doors off.
JOHN SMITHERS . I am a police-constable. I took the prisoner, and found nothing on her.
(The prisoner pleaded poverty.)

GUILTY. Aged 36.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Nine Days.

1401.
CHARLES POULTON and
JOHN SMITH were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April, 2 half-crowns and 1 shilling, the monies of
James Simpson, from his person.

JAMES SIMPSON . I live with my parents—my father is an appraiser, in Thornhill-street, Islington. I was playing with some boys on the, 9th of April, in the Chalk-road—I got my hands dirty, and washed them in some water in the road—in pulling out my handkerchief to dry them, I pulled out two half-crowns and two shillings, and they dropped into the rough road—I picked up the half-crowns and one of the shillings, and was look
ing for the other, when the prisoners came up, and Poulton asked me how much I had lost—I told him what I had picked up, and that I was look
ing for another shilling—he asked me to show him what I had found, and I showed it him in my hand—Smith was there at the time, and began searching one of the boys—Poulton then took the two half-crowns out of my hand, and knocked the shilling out of my hand—Poulton said, "I will have four"—Smith took up the shilling and put it into his pocket—they ran off—the boys followed them down the Chalk-road, and called "Stop thief"—Poulton threw stones at them—a gentleman assisted us, and went

for a policeman—when the gentleman was gone for the policeman, Poulton gave me one half-crown, and said that was the half-crown he had taken from me—when Smith took my shilling—I took him by the collar and held him, and said I would have it—he pushed me and said he had not got it—that he bad got three shillings from the Gas Company, but he had not got my shil
ling, but I am quite sure he had it—the policeman came and took them both.

JOHN BRIGHTMAN . I was playing with the prosecutor—in pulling out hit handkerchief he pulled out two half-crowns and two shllings—he found the two half-crowns and one of the shillings—Poulton took the two half-crowns, and Smith picked up the shilling when it fell from hit hand—the prosecutor seized Smith by the collar—I saw Poulton give the prose
cutor one half-crown, and when he was taken, another half-crown was found on him.

JAMES COLLETT . I was at play. What has been stated is correct—when the prisoners ran away, we boys pursued them, and Poulton threw stones at us—a gentleman on horseback assisted us, and went for a policeman.

JOSEPH YOUNG . I am a policeman. I was called, and went up to the prisoners—the prosecutor said they had robbed him of two half-crowns, and a shilling—Poulton said, "I only took one half-crown, which I have given him again"—I took them both to the station-house—I found 3s. on Smith, which he at first said was his own—he afterwards said 1s. belonged to the boy, which he was willing to give him—I found one half-crown on Poulton.
Poulton. That half-crown and 21/2d., belonged to me—I took but one half-crown, and that I gave him again.
(Poulton received a good character.)

POULTON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Six Months.

1402.
CORNELIUS CONNELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 4lbs. weight of lead, value 6d., the goods of
Henry Collin Johnson, and fixed to a building; against the Statute, &c.

PAUL KINGSTON . I am in the employ of Mr. Johnson, a scavenger—the Blackwall rail-road crosses his yard—I saw the prisoner there with a pick-axe on his shoulder—he went to the leaden pipe, which if in the yard, struck it on each side, cut it off, put it under his smock-frock, and went away—I spoke to the policeman about it.

WILLIAM TAPLIN . I am a policeman. Kingston came and told me of this—I saw the prisoner coming out of a marine-store shop, about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's—I went in, and inquired—I pur
sued, and overtook him—I said, "Where is that lead pipe?"—I put my hand on his breast, and found it in his smock-frock.
Prisoner. I told you I picked it up in the railway—I found it cut there, and took it.

COURT. Q. Did you fit the lead to the place? A. Yes, and it appeared to have been cut with some sharp instrument—it could not have been done with the pick-axe, because both the ends of that are pointed.

WILLIAM SHAW . I heard the prisoner say the lead belonged to the rail
way—I held him while the other officer went for the prosecutor—the prisoner asked me to let him go, and keep the pipe.
HENRY COLLIN JOHNSON . This lead is my property. The pipe goes

from my father's house to mine, through my yard—it was covered over and he must have dug three feet to get it—the prisoner had no business in my yard—I have seen him work in the gas-works opposite me.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to work, and met with this bit of pipe in the railway, and I took it up.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1403.
ELIZABETH COLCOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of March, 2 sovereigns, the monies of
James Rayner.

MARY RAYNER . I am the wife of James Rayner, of Nelson-street, Bethnal-green. On the 15th of March I asked the prisoner's parents to let her come and stay with my children while I went to the doctor's, which she did—I had in my drawer a purse containing nine sovereigns—I left the key in the drawer, and when I came back, I sent the prisoner home—on that day week I missed 2 sovereigns—I went to the prisoner at her mother's, and asked her if she had taken them—I said it might be better for her if she owned to it—no one else could have taken it.

WILLIAM PRICE . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner—I asked her if she knew the difference between a sovereign and a shilling—she said she did, and then she told me, voluntarily, that she took the two sovereigns home to her mother.
NOT GUILTY .

1404.
GEORGE BEDFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of April, 1 coat, value 4l., the goods of
John Stewart.

WILLIAM UPTON . I am in the employ of Mr. John Stewart, of Cheap-side. On the 12th of April I had a coat thrown across the block in the shop—I saw the prisoner, about eight o'clock in the evening, walk into the shop, take it off the block, and walk out immediately—he ran and I ran, and called "Stop thief"—I never lost sight of him—he was stopped in Honey-lane-market—he dropped the coat—it was taken up and given to me—this is it—I am sure the prisoner is the person who took it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was returning home that day, and seeing the coat, I thought I could make a trifle of it, to make up my things, which I had lost—I was half groggy at the time.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arobin.

div1.p:
1405.
BENJAMIN MICHAEL was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of April, 1 box, value 1s. 6d.; 1 gown, value 1l. 5s.; 1 shawl, value 1l. 5s.; 7 yards of printed cotton, value 7s.; 1 cloak, value 10s.; 3 frocks, value 5s.; 1 cape, value 8s.; part of a weighing-machine, value 5s.; 4 pinafores, value 10s.; 1 veil, value 30s.; 2 dishes, value 2s.; 60 plates, value 2s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Smith; and 1 coat, value 3l. 10s., and 1 waistcoat, value 15s.; the goods of
John Rushby.

RICHARD LEE . I am a potato-salesman, in Spitalfields market. Between seven and eight o'clock, on the 12th of April, I was opposite the Mint, and as I entered the Minories I saw a van, and the prisoner walking behind it, trying to get a box from it—I suspected him, as the van was going along, and

watched him—he kept trying to get it at different turnings, and opposite Rosemary-lane he tried again, without effect—opposite the Mint he took the box out of the tail of the van—I let him go about ten yards with it—I ran immediately, caught hold of him, and charged him with stealing it from the van—he said, "You did not see me"—I called the policeman, who came and took him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far did you watch the man? A. From the top of the Minories at Aldgate, up to the Mint—I have tried to get into the City Police, my father being a liveryman—I did not suc
ceed, on account of my height—I was never accused of any thing wrong—I know Esther Haynes—I was not employed to whitewash a room of hers—she never accused me of taking 1l. 5s. out of her drawer—I know Charlotte Lawton—I never pretended to her that I was a widower, that my wife was buried in Stepney-churchyard, and want her to marry me—I did not show her my wife's grave—she came after me—my wife was living at the time, and is now—Lawton lent me two sovereigns—I paid her again, and have the receipt to prove it.

Q. Why not stop the man before, and not wait till he took the box; why not tell the carman somebody was trying to rob him? A. I cannot tell my reason—the box was very heavy, he could hardly carry it—I will take my oath he had it on his hip.

JOHN RUSHBY . I am a builder, and live in Lincolnshire. I was with my van, the carman was driving it, who I employed to take the goods to the wharf—I was called to stop, which I did, and missed the box—I saw the prisoner in custody of a policeman, and the box was produced—there was a coat of my own in it, and the other property belonged to my sister, Elizabeth Smith.
Cross-examined. Q. What sort of a van was it? A. A four-wheeled van—the box was at the back part of it—not fastened—it could not have fallen out, for it was too far in, and the tail-board was up.

JAMES SMITH . I am a policeman. I heard the cry of "Policeman," and saw Lee holding the prisoner in one hand and the box in the other—he charged him with taking it—the prisoner immediately said he did not take it, that it fell from the van and he picked it up.

(Ephraim Jacobs, Pastrycook, Old Castle-Street, Whitechapel;——Isaacs, furrier, Middlesex-street, Whitechapel; and Stephen Baylis, hair-dresser, Middlesex-street, Aldgate, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1406.
JOHN UPTON was indicted
for a rape.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Third Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1407.
SARAH ROUSE was indicted
for a misdemeanor, to which she pleaded

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Months.

1408.
ROBERT PHILPOT was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
John Childs.

CHARLES M'EROY . I am policeman. On the 6th of March, be
tween

eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was on duty in Aldersgate-street—I went to the Castle and Falcon tap-room—there was some alter
cation there—there were thirteen or fourteen individuals in the room, and a woman among them—John Childs, the deceased, was there, and the pri
soner, who is the landlord of the house—they were wishing him to stand half a gallon of beer—he said he would not, and he would not draw any more beer—he then took some pots off the table, went to the bar, closed the door, and put the light out in the bar—he then came into the tap-room, laid hold of the table which I was leaning against, and threw the pots off on to the floor—he was the worse for liquor—he was gathering the pots off the ground, and had some of them in his hand when I came out of the tap-room—as I came out I saw the deceased with his arm up towards the gaslight, and as I passed out at the door I saw the light go out—I have no doubt he turned the gas off—as I passed out of the passage the deceased passed me, running and laughing, and the prisoner followed him with a quart pot in his right hand, and three pint pots in his left hand—they passed me up the yard, and I saw the prisoner strike the deceased first with the quart pot on the back—he then made a hit at him with his left hand with the three pots, which missed him—the deceased turned round to look behind him, and the prisoner with his right hand struck him on the left ear with the quart pot that he held in that hand—the deceased then cried out "Don't murder me," and was in the act of stooping to pick up his hat, which had fallen off, when the prisoner made another blow at him with the right hand, and seeing a scuffle between them I ran up—he picked up his hat—the prisoner was aiming another blow at him with his right hand when I jumped in between them and re
ceived the blow on my right shoulder—he made another blow with his left hand which I caught on my breast—I got hold of him by the arm, and he struggled several times more to get at him, which I prevented—I had not heard the deceased say any thing to Philpot before these blows, not after he came out of the house—what was said inside I did not notice—I turned round to look at the deceased, to see how he was hurt—the prisoner then caught up the deceased's bundle, and made towards the house—the deceased called out, "Don't rob me as well as murder me"—I followed him into the house with the deceased, and told him the deceased gave him into custody, and as such he must think himself—he then had a conversation with the de
ceased—he seemed very repentant to him for what had occurred, and wished him not to press any charge against him, as he had nobody to take care of his house, except he called his wife up—the deceased said he would not, and they had some brandy together—the deceased was bleeding at the ear—I took him over to the hospital to have his ear dressed, and left him in the street afterwards—he said he was going home—they did not keep him in the hospital—they sewed the ear up with one stitch—I interfered as soon as I could—they were some distance from me at first.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. They were dreadful blows you got, were they not? A. No, not very—I did not show them to any me
dical man—when I went into the room, they were chaffing at one another—they were men who had been labouring in the yard, I believe—they all appeared friends—the prisoner wished to clear his house of them, and was persuading them to go—it was a glass of neat brandy they had together after it was over—the prisoner advised me to take the man to the hos
pital—I called on him next morning, and he went with me to see the man

—they chatted together, and shook hands then—the prisoner appeared very anxious to know how he was—they went back to the public-house together, and drank half-and-half together—I did not hear the prisoner ask him to stay to breakfast, nor hear the deceased say, "I own myself in fault"—they staid together about twenty or twenty-five minutes while I was there—I believe the man lived twelve days after this.

STEPHEN BURTENSHALL . I am a watchman, and live in Little Britain. I was on duty at the Castle and Falcon, between eleven and twelve o'clock on this night—I went into the tap-room, and they were all drinking toge
ther in good humour, when I came out—I went in again to call the policeman out, and said the sergeant was going by—the prisoner was then talking along with them—the deceased was laughing and joking with them also—I turned, and came out, and Childs, the deceased, came out laughing directly after-wards—the prisoner followed him with two or three pots in his hand—the de
ceased came running down the yard, and the prisoner after him twenty-five or thirty yards—he then overtook him, and struck him in the left side of the ear with a quart pot—he then up with his hand to strike him again, and the policeman rushed in between them, but did not reach him to hit him—the policeman asked him something, and he up with both hands to strike the de
ceased again, but he hit the policeman instead of him, with one hand on the breast, and the other on the top of the shoulder—they stood there talking a little while, and then went in to have something to drink, all of them, but what passed then, I do not know—I saw the deceased at the same public-house next evening, with his head tied up.

Cross-examined. Q. What was he doing there? A. Nothing—I did not see him drinking or smoking—it was about nine o'clock—there were only about five or six people there—I had not seen him at all in the course of the day.

JOHN STEPHENS . I am a surgeon. The deceased was brought to St. Bartholomew's hospital on Wednesday, the 6th of March—he had a wound on the left ear, which divided the ear, and a slight bruise behind the ear—they might have been done by a pot—he was not drunk, he had been drinking—I dressed the ear, and did what I thought necessary—I pro
posed his stopping in the hospital, but he wished to go home—he seemed a respectable young man—I desired him to come again, but did not see him again alive—I assisted Mr. Lewis in making a post-mortem examination—he died from erysipelas on the head—that might have been occasioned by the blow on the head—he had no signs of erysipelas about him when he came to me.

Cross-examined. Q. Would not drinking raw brandy be very apt to bring it on? A. Not likely to bring it on, but very likely to increase it, it would not cause it without a wound—I should think it a very im
proper course to pursue after a wound however slight—it did not appear to me a severe wound when he came to me—I put a suture in to unite the two parts, and gave him some opening medicine—he was quite sen
sible, and did not appear stunned by the blow—if he had taken proper care of himself, and abstained from liquor, and done as I desired him, it is probable erysipelas might not have come on.

DAVID LEWIS . I am a surgeon, and live in Artillery-place, Bunhill
row. I was called to the deceased at twelve o'clock at night, on the 18th of March—I found he had erysipelas on the face and head—that might arise from any cause—it did not appear more than erysipelas in common

—when I was called in I did not inquire about marks on the head only they told me he had acut, for which he had been in the hospital—his face and head were covered with erysipelas—he died on the 27th—I tried the best medicines I could to cure it—they failed—I was present at the opening of the body, and fully agree with Mr. Stephens.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you also agree with him that drinking ardent spirits, and such things, would be highly improper? A. Certainly—the prisoner behaved in the kindest possible manner during the man's illness—he sent him wine from his house, which was necessary—he told me to do all I could, and he would pay every expense.

MARGARET DENMAN . I attended the deceased during his illness—the ery
sipelas commenced by the side of his head, near his ear—I had seen him on the 5th, and he seemed quite well then—I believe he was thirty-two years old.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was it before he took to his bed? A. On the 17th—I think he was at home, sitting by the fire-side during the previous week—I am not aware that he went to a public-house—he might have done so without my knowledge—I did not see him on the 7th—I cannot say whether I saw him on the 18th—he was walking about—he frequently called on me in the morning, saying he was going to the hos
pital—I live next door to him.

THOMAS RAWLINS . I am ostler at the Castle and Falcon. I was in the public-house on the night in question, and saw the deceased there—he said he would have another pot, or else he would have a lark to night—the landlord brought in a pot, and then attempted to shut up the bar—he then went into the room again to gather up the pots—the deceased sat on the table on my right hand, and said he would have a lark—he jumped on the table, put the gas out, and ran away, and the landlord followed him—I saw them together next morning, and heard the deceased say be was more in fault himself than the landlord was the night before.

HENRY COX . I am porter at the Castle and Falcon. On the day after the occurrence, I was in the tap of Philpot's house—the deceased told me he had made it all up, and he was as much to blame as the landlord was—I afterwards went into the tap, and saw him there for three days after-wards, and every time he was taking refreshment, smoking and drinking—the deceased told me the prisoner gave him 5s. for the loss of his two days' work.

JURY to MR. STEPHENS. Q. Are you able to say whether the erysi
pelas came on in consequence of the blow, or might it have come on in consequence of drink? A. I think it would not have come on except from the blow, but it became more fatal from drink—I think the blow was quite sufficient cause for erysipelas, but if the man had paid more attention to himself it might not have been fatal.

GUILTY of an Assault only. Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1409.
DAVID JULPH and
CHARLES PRICE were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April, at Edmonton, 1 ewe, price 1l. 5s., the pro
perty of
Susannah Nash—2nd COUNT, for killing the same, with intent to steal the carcase; and that they had been previously convicted of felony.
JAMES COCKERELL . I am in the employ of Mrs. Susannah Nash, of Edmonton. I counted her sheep about six o'clock on Tuesday, the 9th

of April, and there were thirty-four ewes—they were in the two-acre field—I counted them again on Wednesday morning, and one ewe was gone, marked with "N"—I found the skin at the top of another field, in the tide of the hedge, the entrails laid by it, and were warm—I have seen two legs, two shoulders, and some more mutton since, and have matched them with the skin—the knuckles came in at the right place—I bare no doubt it belonged to the skin.

GEORGE ANGUS . I work for Mrs. Nash. On Tuesday, the 9th of April, about twelve o'clock, I was in the field minding the sheep, and saw the two prisoners in the road, looking over the hedge into the field where the sheep were—I counted the sheep with Cockerell, in the even
ing, and there were thirty-four—I missed one next day.

NELSON SMITH . I am a policeman. I was sent for on this occasion—I went into the field and saw footsteps of two persons, which lead to the end of Sweetbriar-walk, about three quarters of a mile from the field—I obtained a search-warrant, and went to Julph's house—he lives with his mother, and Price lodges there occasionally—I found the two prisoners in bed together, at least Julph was in bed, and Price at the foot of the bed, partly dressed—I searched the premises, and found in a box which was locked, two shoulders, two legs, and part of a loin of mutton—I have compared that with the skin, and am certain it belonged to it—I compared the prisoners' shoes with the footmarks in the field, and they quite matched—they are both very peculiar shoes—there was blood on the pair belong
ing to Price—when I took them, Price attempted to get out of window, but a man I had placed outside prevented him.

Julph. Q. Are you certain the shoes you had belonged to me? A. Yes, they are the shoes you took off—I did not order you to put them on, you had them on—Price had not his shoes on, but he put them on without my asking him to do so.
Julph's Defence. The shoes did not belong to me—I did not steal the sheep.
Prices Defence. I am innocent of it.

JOSEPH ALDER . I produce a certificate of both the prisoners' former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoners are the persons—they were convicted together, and sentenced to be transported for life.

JULPH—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

PRICE—
GUILTY , Aged 18.

1410.
MARY ROWLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of April, 1 quartern of flour, value 9d. the goods of
John Bell.

MARY ANN BELL . I am the wife of John Bell, a corn-chandler. On the 12th of April, about half-past six o'clock, the prisoner came into the shop for a pint of split-peas and some oats—while I was gone round for them, I missed a quartern of flour—I told her she bad got my property in her apron—she said she had nothing of mine—I took hold of her wrist, and took the flour out of her lap—she resisted, and burst the bag open—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. LORD. Q. Did she offer to pay for the flour? A. No—she said nothing whatever about it—it was on the counter—she had her apron up before her, and I suspected her.
REBECCA STANNARD . I was in the parlour, and saw the prisoner come
in and ask for a pint of split-peas and a pint of oatmeal—I saw her take the flour off the counter and put it into her apron.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the parlour-door open? A. Yes—Mrs. Bell accused her of it—I went to her assistance, and stopped her—I heard no
thing about her paying for it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 49.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.

1411.
ELIZABETH ROACH was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of February, 1 breast-pin, value 5s.; 1 pair of scissors, value 2s.; 2 spoons, value 3s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 3s.; and 2 towels, value 1s. 10d.; the goods of
Ann Walton, her mistress.

ANN WALTON . I live in Pancras-lane, Queen-street. I employed the prisoner as a charwoman for about twelve months—I lost the articles stated—these are them—(looking at them)—she had the opportunity of taking them—I never authorised her to take them.
JOHN JAMES MOORE . I am a pawnbroker. I have produced all these articles—they were pawned at our house by the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence (written.)"The prosecutrix took 4s. 6d. from my wages for the silk handkerchief—I lived with her twelve months, at 4s. a week, and went from seven o'clock in the morning till three in the after-noon, frequently without meat or drink—I afterwards returned home to my sick husband without the means of buying a meal."

ANN WALTON
re-examined. I had two handkerchiefs lost unconnected with this charge, and I have lost a great many articles, but I have so many persons about me I was afraid to suspect any one in particular—I told her this was the second handkerchief I had lost, and I should take 6d. A week of her wages for the first—my agreement was that she should come at seven o'clock in the morning and leave at ten, but she thought proper to keep about the house till three—she has no sick husband to my knowledge.

GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Three Months.

1412.
JOHN BURNHAM was indicted
for an indecent assault.

GUILTY .**—
Confined Two Years.

1413.
EDWARD WILLIAMS and
GEORGE DONALD BAYNTON were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

JOHN BROWNING . I am shopman to Mr. Folkard, a pawnbroker, in the London-road. On the 17th of December, the prisoner Williams came and asked if I would take in a piece of flannel—I said, "Yes"—he said, "It is the usual quality and quantity that I bring to your house"—he did not bring it then, but he stepped outside, and Baynton came in with him, with this piece of flannel—(producing it)—I asked Wil
liams what he wanted for it—he said 9l.—I asked what quantity there was—he said 138 or 140 yards—I am confident he said that—Baynton was present, but he took no part—I counted the folds, and found there

was nothing like the quantity he specified—I said, "There cannot be that quantity of yards"—Williams said, "I will forfeit my life if there is not that number"—it was laid in rather better than half-yard lengths—I said I did not consider there was above 90 or a 100 yards—Williams said I was mistaken, they were all marked at the end, and he pointed out to me the mark on the flannel—138 was marked on it in red chalk—I said it was very strange that I could not make that number—he said he would forfeit his ex
istence if there was not that number of yards, which was there marked—he said, "You have taken in flannel of me before, and you never disputed my word before"—he then produced a duplicate from Mr. Jones, a pawnbroker, of a piece of flannel, pawned for 8l.—he said, "Your neighbours do not doubt my word, and why should you?"—I said, "Well, as you say there is that number of yards I will lend you 6l., and to end the dispute, I had better measure it"—he said, no, he could not allow that, as he served shops, the flannel was done up on a machine, and if it was undone, neither he nor I could do it up in the same way again—I said then "You had better take what I offer you"—he said that would not do, he must have more money, he said the flannel was worth 3s. a yard—I said then I would lend him 7l.—he said, no, I must make it 8l.—I then said, "Well, I will make it the other half-sovereign"—I lent him 7l. 10s., and made out the ticket in the usual way, and gave him the money—I did not put the quantity on the ticket—they then left the shop together—this is the flannel—it has been unpacked, and measured since, and it is 88 yards—I had taken in pieces of flannel of him before, and he has taken them out five or six times.
COURT. Q. Can you form any judgment as to what that is really worth? A. I asked a person in the trade, and he said he could buy it at 1s. 3d. a yard.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Would you have advanced the money you did, on that piece of flannel, if you had thought it contained no more than it really does? A. I should not, a shilling a yard is the utmost I should have lent upon it—in the evening of the same day, Baynton came to the shop, and asked me to take in another piece of flannel—he did not bring it—I asked him if it was the same quality—he said, "Yes, just the same"—I asked what it contained—he said the usual quantity, about 138 or 140 yards—he wanted 8l. on that—I offered him 7s.—he would not take that—he took 7l. 10s.—he went outside, and brought in the flannel—I did not look at the mark on that piece, at the time, but I have measured it since, and there are 80 yards—it appears to me to be the same kind of flannel as the first piece—1s. a yard is as much as I would have advanced on it—I did not see either of the prisoners again, till I was at the Mansion House—a woman called on me, and from what I heard I measured the flannel.
COURT. Q. In what place of custody had the flannels been kept? A. In our warehouse, I rolled them up myself, and the boy took them up stairs.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many shopmen have you? A. Two, besides me and the warehouse boy—I had the flannels about a fortnight before I measured them—only those persons who are in the busi
ness have access to them—it is not worth more than 1s. a yard for a pawn-broker to lend.

Q. What is the proportion between what a pawnbroker lends, and the real value? A. Two thirds, if I think a thing would fetch 5s., I lend 4s. on it—I am not a judge of flannel—fine flannel would be very cheap it 1s. 3d. a yard, but this is very thin—flannels may run from 3s. to 4s. or 5s. a yard—Williams had pawned with me five or six times before, but Baynton had not—Williams has left flannel a week or a fortnight before he redeemed it—on all the other occasions it was flannel he pawned. I had not had disputes with him about the quantity before, as I always made them within ten or a dozen yards of what he stated.

Q. How happened it, as you had all this chaffering, you did not put the number of yards on the duplicate? A. I supposed I was dealing with an honest man—if I had measured it, I should have done it—we are answer
able for the number of yards we put on—I believe it is the custom of manufacturers who have articles by them, to pawn them for the purpose of getting ready money, and then redeem them—that is the reason I took the prisoner's word.
COURT. Q. Did you measure either of the pieces that he redeemed? A. No, I did not—he had not left any of them as long as three weeks—it was sometimes only three days.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Hand in the duplicates which relate to these two pawnings? A. Here they are—here is eighty yards on one, and eighty-eight on the other—that was put on about a fortnight after I took the flannel in—at the time I measured this, it was placed in the usual place where we keep pledges—when the discovery took place, they were done up just the same as when I took them in—they appeared to have been done up by a machine—there was no possibility of their having been undone and done up again.

JAMES SMITH . I am shopman to Mr. Summers, a pawnbroker in Bath-street, City-road. On the 4th of January, Baynton came and asked if I would take a piece of flannel in—I said, "How many yards is it?"—he said, "A piece, 138 yards"—I said, "I will look at it"—in a few minute he and Williams came in together, and brought the flannel—I said, "Well, how much?"—Williams said "10l."—I said "Who is the owner of it?—Williams said, "It is all the same, this is my son," pointing to Baynton—I said, "Well, there is 138 yards, is there?"—Williams said, "No; 140" I said, "One says 138, the other says 140; which am I to understand?" Williams said, "It is a 138 yards piece, but they always run 140 yards"—I said, "How am I to know there is 140 yards?"—he said, "A piece never runs less than 140 yards"—I said, "What, are you the manufac
turer?"—he said he was, and had been so for years—I said, "I don't like to take it unless I measure it"—he said, "You must not measure it, you will disturb it"—I said, "You are a manufacturer, are you not? you can do it up if I can't"—he said, "No, it is done with a machine"—I said, "Well, you have machines"—he said, "No, there are none in this town"—I said, "Well, if you will not allow me to undo it, I don't like to take it; I know nothing of you; have you a card?"—he said, "No; but here is the ticket of a pawnbroker, who I have been doing business with a number of years"—he showed it me—I said, "Why don't you take it there again?"—he said, "I don't like to take so much to one place"—I said "This has not been out above a day or two"—he then said, "The car
riage conies to so much"—I then began to count the folds, and he stopped me—I said, "We can ascertain a little by that, I think;" and by count
ing

the folds I made it about 89 yards—he said, "You can't tell any thing by that; I will vouch there is 140 yards, or else I will forfeit my life"—I said I should not like to lend any thing like that upon it—he slid, "What will you lend?"—I said, "Bring me two pieces, and I will lend you 10l."—he said, "I can't bring two pieces now, what will you lead on this?"—I said, "I will take it in for 1s. a yard"—he pretended to be astonished at that, saying the value was so much more—he at last left it on what I supposed was 1s. a yard—he represented it 140 yards, and I lent him 7l. on it, supposing it was that—I believed it to be 140 yards, oft his representation, he appearing to be a respectable man—Mr. Summers measured it the following day, and thinking he might be mis
taken, I measured it myself, four or five days afterwards, and made it the same as he did, 90 yards—here is the counterpart of the duplicate, on which I afterwards put the quantity it measured—this is the duplicate I gave the prisoner—I gave Williams 7l., deducting the ticket-money—when I gave it him he asked me if would take another piece in in the morning—I said I would ask Mr. Summers, and if he liked to call in the morning, I would give him an answer—I did not see either of the prisoners again till the Monday following, when Baynton brought another piece—I said, "You represented what you brought before as 140 yards, and there is only 90; you know you defrauded me"—he said, "I know there was 140 yards"—I said, "You know there was only 90"—he said, "Then you won't have the other piece?"—I said, "Have the other piece! no, you had better go and mind what you are doing for the future;" and he went away.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long was that after the first pawning? A. The following Monday—I believe the first was on the Friday—I said, "You had better leave me this piece to make up for the one you left," and he made a jeer at me—I said nothing about his paying me the money for the piece he had left, and taking it back again—some articles may be worth nearly the money we lend at the time, but at the end of the year may not be worth half the money—in taking an article like flannel, we estimate the value as if it would remain in out hands for twelve months, and then probably it may not have a good sale—we get fifteen per cent on the money lent—flannel at the end of the year would be much less likely to sell than silver and other things—it is liable to moth and other things—this flannel would fetch more if sold in a shop than at our sale—I think this might fetch 1s. 6d. a yard at the sale.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Are you obliged to sell these things by auction at the end of a year? A. Yes—there is the auctioneer's commission to pay, also moving, and other expenses, which we take into account.

JAMES MASTERS HOWIE . I am shopman to Mr. Johnson, of Bishops
gate-street, a pawnbroker. On Saturday, the 5th of January, Baynton asked me if I would take in some flannel—I told him I would, provided it was all right, and I had the owner present when I took it in—he said he would bring it on the Monday, and on Monday both the prisoners came, about three o'clock in the afternoon, with a piece of flannel done up in folds, which I produce—I asked what they wanted upon it, and Williams said, 10l.—I asked him what quantity of yards it contained—he said, "137," and at the same time he referred me to the mark at the end of the flannel in red chalk, 137—he said that was the mark of the number of yards it contained—I said, "How am I to know that?"—he said, "I am

the manufacturer of the article, and I will forfeit my existence if it is not all right and correct"—I said if that was the case I would advance him money upon it, but I should not like to lend him so much as that—he said he had been obliged to advance money that morning to make up a bill, and showed me a duplicate of a piece he had pledged that morning at Mr. Cotton's for 9l.—it stated, "Piece of flannel, 137 yards as marked, 9l."—he solicited me to lend him the same on this piece—I told him I could not, I would lend him 7l. upon it—I gave him 7l., and they both left the shop—both the prisoners were present during the conversation—some informa
tion afterwards reached me, and on the following Friday, the 11th, Baynton came, and asked if I would take in another piece of flannel—I asked him if it was the same description and quality as the other—he said, "Yes," and he would bring it on the following day—I had a policeman there the next day, and Baynton came about twelve o'clock with a piece of flannel—I asked him the quantity of yards it contained, and if it was the same description as the other—he said, yes, it was of the same description, and much about the same length, 139 yards, and I found a mark of 139 on the end—I said if there was the quantity of yards I would advance him the same money as I had done on the piece on Monday—I took a dupli
cate out of the drawer, and pretended to write it out for him—the officer then came into the shop, and I said, "I shall not take this piece in with
out measuring it"—Baynton said, "You must not do that, you will spoil the appearance of the flannel," and he referred me to the mark on it—I said I felt confident that was not the case, that I had been defrauded in one instance by himself and the elder party who was with him, and he was now attempting it again—he said the property did not belong to him, but to his father, who was waiting outside—while this was going on Williams came in, and asked Baynton what be was doing there so long, or why he was wait
ing—Baynton replied that he was given into custody—Williams asked who by, and if there was any money given for the piece—I said, no, and as I suspected this piece was the same as the last, I should give the officer charge of him also—I gave charge of them both—these are the pieces of flannel—the first piece taken on the 7th of January has been measured, and contains 79 yards—both ends of this are marked—on the outer end is 137, and on the inner end 78—on the one brought on the 11th is 139—this has been measured, and contains 86 yards.
COURT. Q. Are you acquainted with the trade so as to know what the outside mark denotes? A. No; it was represented to me as the quantity it contained.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You have put down the number I see on the duplicate? A. Yes, I did that when I got it.

HENRY RICHARDSON . I am shopman to Mr. Cotton, a pawnbroker, in Shoreditch. In the beginning of January Williams came to my master's shop—he asked if I would take in some pieces of flannel to the amount of 10l. or 20l.—I said I would not take in more than 10l.—he said he was a manufacturer of it, and it was a bad time of year to dispose of it—on the 7th of January he called with two pieces of flannel, and Baynton was then with him—it must have been between twelve and one o'clock—the two pieces were put on the counter, and Williams represented that there were 37 yards in each piece, referring me to a mark at the end of them in red chalk—I thought, from the previous conversation I had had, that that was the 10l. worth, and I was going to make a ticket for 10l. with very little

conversation on the subject—Williams then said he wanted 10l. on each piece, and that I had misunderstood him—I said I could not think of lend
ing 10l. on each piece, that I did not consider they were of that value to me and I would not take in more than one piece—he said, "137 yards of fine flannel surely you will lend me 10l. on?"—I said I could not—I reckoned it up, and offered him 9l. on it—he agreed to take it—I was going to make out the ticket, and I said, "It is rather awkward, how am I to call this a piece of flannel?" and he showed me a ticket of Mr. Fleming's, on which was "137 yards of fine flannel, as marked," and I made mine out the same—he referred me to the mark of 137 on the flannel—I made out the ticket on the faith of what he represented, and they went away—on the same day I received a communication from Mr. Cotton, and just after that Baynton came to the shop again—I was in the parlour—I asked him into the parlour—I said I was very much afraid I could not make the number of yards, I had tried it, and could not make more than 100—he said he was certain there was, and referred me to the mark—he said it was measured in the manufacturing districts—I asked if he would allow me to measure it—he said no, it could not be done up in London in the same form, and it would spoil the sale—I said it placed me in a very awkward situation—he said he would go and speak to his father.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Did Williams, when you took the first piece, say there was 137 yards? A. He both pointed to the mark and said there was—I have taken in small quantities of flannel at different times—I suppose this to be worth 1s. 6d. or 1s. 10d. a yard—I consider at our sale it would fetch that—it is a bad time to sell flannel in January, February, or March, and that I took into consideration, as we should have to sell it at a lower rate.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Have you measured it since? A. Yes, there are 94 yards—there are marks at each end—on the inner end is "1734," and on the top "137."

FRANCIS COTTON . I am a pawnbroker. I have one shop in Shoreditch, and one in Hackney-road—on the 7th of January I was in my shop in Hackney-road—about the middle of the day the two prisoners came in and brought a piece of flannel, but I did not take it in—it was in flat folds—I forget the sum they asked for it, but it was 9l. or 10l.—I asked what quantity there was, and they said the quantity was marked on it, 137, pointing to a red chalk mark on the outer end—my young man was attending to the prisoners, and I asked him if he had measured it—he said, "No"—I said I could not tell what there was without—they said they would not have it measured on any account, as it would put it out of con
dition, and those marks on the flannel were made in the country by author
ised registered men—they showed me a ticket which my young man had given them, and that of Mr. Fleming's.
Williams's Defence. They were my own goods, and I meant no harm—my step-son merely carried a piece or two—he knows nothing about it. (The prisoners received good characters.)

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY —
Confined Three Months.

BAYNTON—
GUILTY —
Confined One Month.

1414.
JOHN DAVIES was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. BALLANTINE declined the prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

1415.
CHARLES BEGBIE was indicted
for perjury.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1416.
JOHN THOMPSON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

SUSANNAH BURNS . I am the wife of Patrick Burns, he belongs to the Royal Artillery. On the 9th of March we were at the Tower—the prisoner who was a stranger, came to me and inquired for my husband, Patrick Burns—he said he was my mother's brother's son—he said he had come from Ireland, and he had brought me a box weighing four cwt. containing tea and sugar, soap, chocolate, seven silk handkerchiefs, and some silk dresses, a cage and two parrots—he said he had brought it from abroad for me, and asked if I had any money, he wanted 2s. 6d. he said, to release this box from the Custom-house—I gave him half-a-crown—he said that was not sufficient, and I gave him a shilling more—he said, "Cousin, don't think I want to do you any harm, don't think I would take any thing from you, I would rather give you something"—he sat down a few minutes, and then went away, and I never saw him again till my husband took him—I never got my box—my husband met him on the Sunday, the next day, and said, "Come along with me, you have robbed my wife"—he said, "Take my coat and hat, and 11d. in halfpence, and let me go"—he said, "No, I will give you in charge."
THOMAS COOPER . I am an officer. I took the prisoner into custody from Patrick Burns.
Prisoner's Defence. I did it from perfect hunger and distress—I had not had a morsel of food for two days—I had been for two nights on the bridges of London.

GUILTY .* Aged 31.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1417.
WILLIAM KEENE was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

CHRISTOPHER GARNER . I am a labouring man residing in Kent. I became entitled to some premises at Shore ham, and at Horsham, which was left me by my grandfather, and considering the prisoner an attorney, I employed him to get possession for me—I employed him as a lawyer, and had paid him before this from 15l. to 20l.—when I spoke to the pri
soner about it, he told me he was clerk to Mr. Collyer, in Chancery-lane, and that be was authorised to act for him, and to use Mr. Collyer's name—he said he was carrying on the proceedings to aid me in getting posses
sion of my property—he told me he wanted money to carry that on—I gave him 5l. on the 9th of March, in consequence of what he said—he was to carry on the business for me—I was to go to Maidstone, and see him there on the 11th of March, but he was not there—I never got my 5l. back.

Prisoner. Q. Have you got any account of the money you paid me? A. No, I know I paid you from 15l. to 20l.—I did not tell you when you wrote to me for money in the country to write for twice as much as you wanted, to deceive my sister—you wrote to me once for 1l., and when I came you wanted two.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not accompany you to Kemsden, and to Shoreham, and serve ejectments? A. You served something, I do not know what—my sister saw all the letters that came, for I could not read them.
SAMUEL COLLYER . I am a solicitor, and live in Chancery-lane. I

have known the prisoner twenty-four or twenty-five years in different offices, but neither he nor any other person was authorised to use my name in law proceedings—I knew nothing of this transaction till the prosecutor called on me.

Primer. Q. Have you never authorised me to use your name? A. Never, I never gave you authority to lodge detainers against persons in custody—I signed two discharges for persons in Whitecross-street prison, Prisoner. You know there is an application about being made to the Court this term, on account of your allowing unqualified men to use your name. Witness. I know nothing about it. I know a person of the name of Wood, he is my clerk—over my door is E. A. Wood, and Mr. Collyer's offices—he is the housekeeper—both the houses belong to him—I have no person whom I allow to practice in my name—I was in the habit of calling on you almost every Sunday when you lived in Clerkenwell, but I never settled an account with you—I have a writing clerk of the name of Lewis Dolby—he is paid according to his labour—I never asked you to accept a bill for 200l.—I never heard of such a thing—I never asked you how you came on when you went into Kent—I never knew you went there—I had two or three letters from Kent—I do not know who they came from—I received a packet containing 4l. 15s., and I gave it to you.

JOHN VERYAN . I am a porter in Farringdon-market. I know the prosecutor—on Saturday the 9th of March, I took 5l. to the prisoner, on account of the prosecutor—I put it down, and he told me to take half-a-crown for my trouble—here is the bill he gave we for it.
Prisoner. Q. Ought not that to have come on the Friday night? A. Yes, but it did not come till Saturday.

(The prisoner read a long defence, stating that the prosecutor had employed him in the business, and that he communicated his proceedings to Mr. Collyer, who was satisfied—that he had no intention to defraud the prosecutor; and that Mr. Collyer had authorised him to use his name.)

GUILTY. Aged 50.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

1418.
WILLIAM HAWKES was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

SETH BULL . I am a victualler. I had bottled beer of Mr. Drybrough—he used to allow me 3s. a dozen for the empty bottles—on the 2nd of March the prisoner came to me for Mr. Drybrough's bottles, and I de
livered them to him—he said he came from Mr. Drybrough for the empty bottles—I cannot say exactly that I believed him, because I had had a note from Mr. Drybrough a fortnight before, saying he had been robbed to a great extent, and he would send his book with the person who came for them in future—I let the prisoner have six dozen of bottles, and then I asked to look at his book, and he had not got one—he took the bottles off my premises—I followed him and came up with him—he made some excuse, stating that the man would bring the book presently—I took him into custody—the man did not come with the book.

Prisoner. Q. How far did I take them? A. Not more than two or three yards—you carried them off my premises—I detained you, and told you to bring them in, which you did—you called on me two days before, and I should have given you them then, but I had not time.
ANDREW DRYBROUGH . I serve the prosecutor with bottled beer—I did not send the prisoner for any bottles—I never saw him in my life till at Worship-street—he went quite without my knowledge.

Prisoner's Defence. I was engaged by a wine-merchant's porter with a truck—he gave me 1s. 6d. to help him draw it—he stopped near Mr. Bull's house—took a basket off and said, "Go to that house, as I come back I will call for you and take the bottles"—I went, and he gave me six dozen and four bottles—I rolled them to the door-post—I could not carry them—Mr. Bull then gave me into custody—he acknowledged at the office that his wife told him that two men came with a truck while he was giving me into custody.

GUILTY . * Aged 45.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1419.
CHARLES DOWNE was indicted
for an indecent assault.
NOT GUILTY .

1420.
JOHN DEACON was indicted
for an assault, with intent to violate
Elizabeth Gunnell.

GUILTY.—Of a common assault.—
Confined One Year.

1421.
BENJAMIN PARKER and
CHARLES NEALL were indicted for
a conspiracy.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1422.
JOHN WILSON was indicted
for assaulting
Elizabeth Beazeley, with intent, &c.; to which he pleaded

1423.
JAMES CHARLES CLIFFORD was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
— SCARLETT. I am marshal to Lord Abinger. I produce the record on which an action was brought on a bill of exchange—this is the bill which was produced at the trial—I have had it ever since.

GEORGE FREDERICK HUDSON . I am a solicitor, and live in Bucklers-bury. I was concerned for the present defendant in 1835—he sent for me to the Queen's Bench Prison, where he was in custody, and gave me a memorandum of his demand against Lady Parker—the paper I have in my hand, I believe are the written instructions he gave me—they are his handwriting—(reads)—"Lady Fanny Parker to J. C. Clifford.—1836: March 11, Bill 40l.; June 30, ditto 21l. 15s. 8d.; up to July 13, ditto 1l. 6s.: Total 63l. 1s. 8d."—I lodged a detainer against Lady Parker—60l. I think was the amount sworn to—I proceeded in the action—these are the particulars of it—(looking at some papers)—the cause came on for trial, and the cause and all matters and differences were referred.
Q. Is this the order of reference? (handing a paper to the witness) A. This is a copy, I rather think—I am not certain it is a copy—I believe it is the original.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. On your oath, are you prepared to swear positively that it is the original? A. No, I would not—I believe that it is.
Q. Look at this paper; read that on the back ?—(reads)—A. "Clifford versus parker. Copy Order of Reference."
MR. JAMES. Q. What is the ordinary practice; are there two originals made out on paper, one for each party? A. I believe there are.
COURT. Q. When a case is referred at Nisi Prius, there are two parties, the plaintiff and defendant, and do you not know that there are two papers given? A. I believe there are.

(Read)—"12th December, in the seventh year, &c. This cause, and all matters and differences, including the rule now pending, between the two parties, are hereby referred to John Busby, Esq., Barrister-at-law, to order what he shall think proper to be done."
Witness. I or my clerk took up the original award, but I have not got it, as I have since delivered all my papers to Mr. Clifford's then attorney.

Q. In February, 1837, was any money paid to you by Mr. Austin in respect of that action? A.
