There was—this is the receipt I gave him for 128l. 10s., in full, for the debt and costs—the debt was 40l. and the rest were the costs—I never saw Mr. Clifford after I gave that receipt—I sent him the balance due to him, which was 26l.—there were 14l., the costs of a rule due from Clifford to me, and I think these were costs out of pocket—I deducted all that was due to me, and sent him the balance—I never saw him again on the subject of tins action.

Q. From the time the action commenced, till the settlement, was any thing ever said to you by Clifford about two bills? A. I believe there never was—he said nothing to me at that time, except about one bill—(looking at a bill)—I believe this to be the bill on which I brought the action.
COURT. Q. What do you mean by the word "believer A. It is now three or four years ago, one does not like to speak positively.

MR. JAMES. Q. Have you a moral certainty in your own mind that that is the same bill? A. I have; I must have had it at the time I took the instructions, or shortly after—my attention was not called particularly to it more than to any other transaction—the prisoner was in the habit of tending from the Bench to me—I have, received letters from Mm, in his handwriting, by French—I sent the money to the prisoner, I think, by my clerk, in February—and in March, 1837, I received a communication from him, and I sent him, by French, the bill on which the action was brought, and some cheques—I believe I sent the bill on which the action was brought—I had no other, but I have said that I am not certain that this is the bill.

Q. Is it your belief, to the best of your memory, that yon sent back this bill of exchange with the cheques by French? A. I cannot speak any other way than to the best of my recollection—not having seen the docu
ment for three years, I will not speak to it more positively—I believe that bill had no indorsement beside Clifford's—that bill was in the same state as this, except that it had not Gibbs's indorsement, which it now has—to the best of my recollection, this is the bill certainly.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you not sworn you were not certain that it was the bill? A. I am not certain other than to the best
of my belief—I will not speak to the certainty of a document I have not seen for three years.

Q. You said you had a moral certainty, what did you mean by that? A. I will give you my definition of it—that while there is a possibility of its not being so from some exact imitation of it, still, as there is no ground for believing it has been imitated, I believe it to be the same—when we see a bill we sometimes see it only once—I saw that perhaps half-a-dozen times—I believe there was no other indorsement on it—I will not say my recollection of it must have been very slight—the reason I will not swear positively to it is because I have not seen it for three years.

COURT. Q. The bill was produced before the arbiter? A. Yes, I had the bill there—the signature to these two affidavits are the prisoner's writing, and this paper of instructions is his writing, (read.)

In the first affidavit, dated 13th September, 1838, the defendant de
posed that Lady Parker was not detained in the King's Bench on or about the 14th July, 1836, on the 40l. bill on which the present action was brought, but on another bill of the same date and amount, which the said Lady Parker had accepted in addition to the first—in the second affidavit, dated 20th October, 1838, he deposed, that when he first instructed his attorney, Mr. Hudson, in 1836, he delivered to him a bill of exchange for £40 on Lady Parker, and that he never bad the said bill back from Mr. Hudson, nor had he, to the best of his recollection, ever seen the same since.

LADY FANNY PARKER . I am widow of the late Sir Hyde Parker—I reside in Park-lane—in the year 1835 I employed the defendant as cook—I was then in the King's Bench—I was indebted to the defendant for cooking—he applied to me for money about December, 1835, and I gave him a bill on the 16th of December—I think Mrs. Grimes was present when the defendant made his application for money—I said I expected money from a verdict against Lord Lake, and that I could not give him any money then—40l. was the amount I then owed him—I think, to the best of my recollection, he delivered me an account at the time he made the applica
tion for some money—I then offered to give him a bill, and a bill was brought up to me to accept, which I did accept, in presence of Mrs. Grimes—the amount was 40l.—this is the bill I accepted at that time—I did not accept two bills, only this one.

COURT. Q. Did you at any time accept two bills of the same date, and for the same amount, 40l.? A. No, that I am sure of—I swear the prisoner made no application to me for payment of a second bill of 40l.

MR. GIBBS. Q. Did Clifford, after that, bring an action against you for that bill? A. Yes, sir, in 1836, I think—the amount of that bill, the debt and costs in that action were paid by Mr. Austin, my attorney—this is an affidavit I made in the cause—the signature is my hand-writing, and the contents of it are true—(read)—This affidavit was dated the 6th of September, 1838, in which the deponent swears, that on or about the 14th of July, 1836, she was detained, in the Bench at the suit of Clifford, and that the particulars of the plaintiff's demand, 88l. 10s., and bill 40l. was, about the 20th of February, paid to the plaintiff's attorney; and that she never, to the best of her recollection, had any other transactions or accounts with Clifford; and that she never, to the best of her recollection or belief, accepted any other bill for 40l. but the one mentioned in the declaration."
Cross-examined by MR. LORD. Q. It was in 1835 you employed the

prisoner as your cook? A. Yes, I went there in 1833, But it was not immediately after that I employed him—I did not give him the money when be first applied—I gave him one bill for 40l., that was the whole of his claim on me at that time—I owed him no more money whatever—he did not give me a bill at that time, to my recollection—I am sure no account was delivered to me at that time—I gave the bill on the 16th of December, in the large room in the state-house—Mrs. Grimes was present—the prisoner had had a cheque or two of mine, two, I think, they were duly paid—every thing was paid at that time but that 40i.—I had had frequent negotiation with him before this bill—I paid him generally in cash in small sums—I never accepted a bill before—I hive never given him a cheque since that time, and all the cheques I gave him prior to that time have been duly paid to the prisoner—I know this cheque for 9l. 4s., 7d., this was included in the money Mr. Austin paid—it was all paid at that time—I am sure this was included—it is prior to December, 1835—when I gave the bill Mrs. Grimes was present—I don't know whether she read the bill—she was close to me, it was at breakfast time, about ten or half-past ten o'clock—I am quite positive there was no other bill that I signed—I never gave any cheque as late at 1836.
MR. GIBBS. Q. Was this one of the cheques you gave previous to the 40l. bill? A. Yes, it is in October, 1835—it was paid at the time of the reference to Mr. Busby.
COURT. Q. Has Mr. Austin indemnified you for the expense of this? A. No.

DANIEL EDWIN AUSTIN . I paid the sum of 128l. 10s. to Mr. Hudson—I had not a bill of exchange in the action Clifford versus Parker re
turned to me by Mr. Hudson, nor did I ask for the award—I have never had the bill from Clifford—I applied to him and Mr. Hudson for it.

COURT. Q. You never received the bill of exchange on which this action was brought, and which was the subject of the case referred? A. No, the order of Nisi Prius was for all matters in difference—there was nothing said about another bill of exchange for 40l., if there had it would have been embraced in the order.

GEOROIANA BEATRICE GRIMES . I am a widow. I reside at Blackheath—I resided with Lady Parker while she was in the Bench, merely as her friend—I don't remember from what time, I think it was about 1833 or 1834, I was there at the latter end of 1835—I remember the defendant calling on Lady Parker for the payment of his bill—I was present—I don't remember that I saw the amount of his claim—her ladyship gave him a bill of exchange to the amount of 40l.—I saw Lady Parker write upon the bill—she did not give more than one bill—after that bill became due I saw the defendant upon it—he did not state to me then that he had two bills on Lady Parker to the same amount.

Cross-examined by MR. LORD. Q. When the prisoner came to Lady Parker for this bill, did he state what the amount of his claim was? A. I don't recollect that he did—he asked for the amount of his bill, but dm not state the amount that I recollect—he did not talk long about the bill, I don't think he was there ten minutes—he asked her if she could pay him his bill—she said she could not, because she had an action pending against Lord Lake, and till that was settled she could not pay him—he then asked her to give him a bill—she said yes—he went out and returned with the bill, which I saw Lady Parker sign—I did not read the bill, but I

heard him say it was for 40l.—he did not say there was more due—Lady Parker never gave any other bill that I know of, neither before nor after—she has frequently given cheques—I don't know how she generally paid the prisoner.
THOMAS PROTHEROE . I am a clerk in the Exchequer Writ Office—I produce an affidavit of debt in the cause of John Rafter against Fanny Parker—the writ is annexed to it.

JOHN THOMPSON . I was articled to Mr. Kirk, Mr. Clifford's late attorney. He was solicitor in the cause of Rafter against Parker—the signature to this affidavit is the signature of Rafter—I think both the prisoner and Rafter came to the office to give instructions to pursue the action—the prisoner was repeatedly there—I cannot say whether he ad
vanced any money to Mr. Kirk, I believe not.

Cross-examined by MR. LORD. Q. Was Mr. Kirk concerned in either of these actions? A. Yes, he took Mr. Rafter's retainer—this bill was often spoken of—I saw Mr. Hudson repeatedly—in preparing the brief it was necessary to have all the papers—he stated he had a faint recollection of two bills, but he had seen only one, he thought the other one was about 10l.—it was a small amount—I think two or three cheques had been given to the prisoner, by Lady Parker, after the award.

JAMES BUCKINGHAM . I am an engineer, and live in Camden-town. I am a client of Mr. Austin's, and know him—in consequence of what he wished me to do, on the 17th of January last, I saw the prisoner, I think it was in Braddam's-row, Newington Causeway, I believe it was his house or lodgings—I had received instruction that he was to be found there—I had never seen him before—he asked me if I was aware for what purpose I had come—(he expected me to come to be a witness on the trial, as Rafter's action was then going on)—Mr. Thompson took me there, and introduced me to the prisoner as Mr. Buckingham—the prisoner asked Thompson if I was the person whom he (Thompson) had mentioned to him—Thompson said, "Yes," and that I was a friend of his, and I had come relative to the matter of which they had been speaking—I asked the prisoner what it was he wanted me to do—he said, "I want you to swear that you went with Thompson to Pitt-street"—(it afterwards transpired that Rafter lived there)—he said I must swear that I went with Thompson, and presented the bill at Drummond's, at Charing-cross—that I was to swear that the bill was not paid—that I then accompanied Thompson to lady Parker's house, which he afterwards told me, was No. 13, Park-lane—he told me that was all he wished me to swear—he then addressed Thomp
son, and told him that he must not only swear what I have mentioned he told me, but that he went afterwards to the King's Bench by himself, bringing the bill, which had been dishonoured, back to Lady Parker, and that it was presented at Lady Parker's, in Park-lane, for payment—after seeing the prisoner in Braddam's-row, I saw him at a coffee-shop, in Newcastle-street, Strand, on the 28th of January—I had appointed to meet him there, through Rafter, whom I had met the previous morning—I was at the coffee-house before the prisoner was—he came in and wished me to accompany him to Mr. Kirk, who, I believe, was his attorney, and was bringing that action—I was to go to have the evidence taken, which he had detailed to me, and he gave me this piece of paper as instructions to swear—he brought the paper written, and I indorsed it within a few minutes—a person of the name of Jenkins was at the coffee-shop, for the purpose of detecting this scheme—I

read this paper over several times, and asked the prisoner particularly if it was his writing—he acknowledged it to be his writing, and said that was what he wished me to swear—he had previously said he would give me 10s. if I would swear, in the Court of Exchequer what he had stated, and when he gave me this paper he said he would give me 14s.

(The instructions were as follows:—" Went with Mr. Thompson to Drum
mond's the bankers, at Charing-cross, to present bill of exchange, 40l., three months, drawn on Parker, paid to Mr. Clifford, endorsed over to Gibbs, and paid to Rafter—have been at Rafter's house in Pitt-street, have seen Gibbs there several times, and know his hand-writing.")

Cross-examined by MR. LORD. Q. By whose request did you go to see the prisoner? A. Mr. Austin's—he stated what he wanted me to go for—I had known Austin some time, but never saw the prisoner till the 17th of January—I went to the house with Thompson, and asked to see Mr. Clif
ford—Thompson told me it was Mr. Clifford, and he assented to it—I neverperformed such a duty fox Austin before, nor any one else—I asked the prisoner if I was to swear what he required, what was I to have—he looked at Thompson, and said, "I suppose we must give him the same at you have," and then Clifford said he would give me 10s.—I said it was very little, and asked him when he should require me—he said the trial would come on on Monday, and he should require me to be at the Exche
quer, in the City—I said, "I suppose Mr. Rafter will pay me"—Rafter was. sitting there at the time—I asked who I was sitting in company with, and the prisoner said, "That is Mr. Rafter"—I said, "Let me look at you, stand up, in case I should be asked, I shall be able to recognise you"—I said, "What is your height?"—he said, "Five feet six inches and three quarters"—no money was paid me—I did not agree to perform this office, I said, "If I did it"—I never went by any other name than Buckingham—I have been an engineer four or five years, under my own patent—I have lived in Camden-town since 1834—I was an agent before I was an engineer—I was never charged with any offence in a court of justice.

EDWARD JENKINS . I am an appraiser and broker, and live in South
ampton-street. I do the business of Covent-garden parish—I went, at the request of Mr. Austin, to a coffee-shop in Newcastle-street, but I cannot say when—I went by myself, and met Mr. Buckingham there—after he had been there some time, the defendant came in, and sat in the next box—the purport of my being there was to overbear what passed-a conversa
tion took place between Clifford and Buckingham respecting a bill of ex
change, which Buckingham was to swear he had protested, and Bucking
ham wanted to know what he was to be paid—Clifford said 10s.—he said that would not pay him, he must have more, and Clifford agreed to give him 14s.—he gave him a paper of instructions, on which was written what he was to do—this is the paper—Buckingham read it over and said, "This, I understand, is what I am to do"—Clifford said, "Yes"—Buck
ingham then went out, and I went immediately after—I was in Court when the cause came on to be tried, and I heard the defendant deny that this paper was his writing most distinctly, or that he had given it to any one.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you in the same room? A. Yes, there were only us three—it is a small room—I did not speak at all—I was there half an hour—it was about eleven or twelve o'clock—Thompson was not there I am certain.
For the defendant, MR. LORD called JACOB CASTELL. I know the prisoner—I have seen him write, but I do

not know that I should be able to swear to his handwriting exactly-(looking at the instructions)—this paper looks like his writing—I have been employed by him to make out accounts occasionally—I have drawn several bills for him—I drew two bills between him and Lady Parker, on the 16th of December, 1835—I only drew the body of the bills—they were for 40l. each—I put in the dates—the reason I drew them for Clifford was be
cause his hand shook so—this is one of the bills—(looking at it)—I did not see the bill after it was drawn, till it was shown to me before I was subpoenaed on the trial of Rafter against Parker—I was subpoenaed on the part of Rafter, and gave evidence—I saw Mr. Buckingham, and had some conversation with him on the Monday evening, four days before that trial—a person of the name of John Thompson came to my room, and he took me to the Brace, and introduced me to Buckingham—Thompson said, "This is Mr. Buckingham; he is going to corroborate my evidence on Thursday, and we are all to be of one mind"—I said I did not know what they were going to prove; all I knew was, I was the drawer of the bill that had been shown me, and I was going to prove it—I said I drew two bills, but whether they were accepted or not I did not know.

MR. JAMES. Q. You drew two bills, did you? A. Yes—the whole of this bill is my hand-writing, except the signature of the drawer—I wrote the direction—Clifford did not sign it in my presence—I did not see it after it was drawn—one of the bills I drew that any was on a wrong stamp, a stamp that would not carry the amount.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month in Newgate, and
Transported for Seven Years.

1424.
JOHN HANCOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of March, 2 pairs of boots, value 5s. 6d., the goods of
John Honey.

JOHN HONEY . I live at Stratford, in Essex, and am a shoemaker. On the 28th of March, about a quarter to nine o'clock in the evening, I was in the room adjoining my shop—I saw the prisoner in the shop, taking two pairs of boots out of the window—he must have lifted the latch to come in—I saw him leave the house, and put the boots in the corner of the next house, which is a public-house, and then cross the road—I followed and secured him—I left him in care of the neighbours, and went and got the boots—I took him about twenty yards from the shop—he saw me follow
ing him, and ran.
JOHN BARTLETT . I am a constable of West Ham. The prisoner was given into my custody, with the boots.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming from llford, on the other side of the road—two boys ran by me, nearly knocked me down with the boots, and chucked them inside the public-house.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

1425.
MARY ANN POTTS and
MARY ANN WILLIS
were in
dicted for feloniously breaking and entering, the dwelling-house of
Thomas Davis, on the 31st of March, at Woolwich, and stealing therein 1 hat, value 2s., the goods of
George Thomas; 1 looking-glass and frame, value 9s.; and 1 blanket, value 2s.; the goods of Thomas Davis; and that Potts had been previously convicted of felony.

GEORGE THOMAS . I am a pensioner and lodge in the kitchen of Thomas Davis, in Powis-street, Woolwich. On Sunday, the 31st of March, be
tween seven and eight o'clock, I missed the articles stated from the front kitchen—they had been all let to me with the lodging, except the hat, which was my own—I had seen them safe about six o'clock, when I went up stairs with the landlord—the door leading to the area was then shut, not locked, bat on the latch—when I came down between seven and eight o'clock, it was open, and the area gate also, and the things gone—there are a few steps down to the area.
Potts. Q. You say your door was latched, it was open? A. No, it was latched—I have not found the pillow, only the glass and hat—I did not see you take them.

JOSEPH BUTTERFILL . I am a constable of Woolwich. I produce a blanket which I got from Mrs. Wood, on Sunday night, the 31st of March, also a glass, which I got from a person named Cross, at the house where the prosecutor lodges, and a hat which I received from Sarah Miles, with some baskets—I went in search of the prisoners, and found them at the Coach and Horses public-house, High-street, Woolwich—I told them I took them in charge for robbing Mr. Thomas of a blanket, a glass, and a hat—Potts denied all knowledge of it—I told her I had got a blanket from Mrs. Wood, which had been left by her the same evening—she denied it—Willis also denied the charge, and said she had received the glass from Potts.

Potts. When you took me you did not name-any thing but the blanket. Witness. Yes, I did, all that was told me, a feather pillow, a hat, and a looking-glass, and you denied knowing any thing about them.

WILLIAM CROSS . I am a private in the Royal Marines at Woolwich. On Sunday, the 31st of March, the two prisoners came to my house, on Church-hill, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening—Willis said she wished to leave the glass till to-morrow morning—that they wanted to dispose of it for 4s., as they were in distress, and it belonged to Potts—my wife said she could not buy it—she said, if my wife could lend her 1s., as she was in distress, and had had no bread all day, she should be obliged.—I lent her 8d., and they went away—I afterwards went in search of the prisoners, and found them at the Coach and Horses—I desired Willis to, come and fetch the glass away, as my wife was very uneasy that it was left—she was just in the act of coming with me, when the constable came in and took her—I asked her if it was come by honestly—she said it belonged to Potts, and Potts said it bad belonged to a seaman—I took the glass to Mr. Davis, and while I was there, the officer came and took it.
Potts. You said if it was stolen, you would put it away? Witness. I said so, and if you had said it was stolen, I should have given you into custody—Willis said it belonged to you.

SARAH MILES . I live at Woolwich. On Sunday night, the 31st of March, I was at the Coach and Horses—the two prisoners came in with two friends, and a sailor came in after, but who he was, or whether he was in their company, I cannot say—Potts had some baskets which she left on
the settle—the landlord told me to take them to Butterfill at the cage, which I did—the hat was in them.

MARGARET WOOD . I am the wife of Alexander Wood, and live at Hop-yard Rails, Woolwich. Between eight and nine o'clock, on Sunday evening, the 31st of March, Potts came to me and showed me a blanket which she wanted to sell—she said it belonged to a young man a sailor, and asked me to let her leave it till the morning—I did so—she looked very ill, and asked me to give her 2d. to get a pint of beer—I gave her 3d.—she said she would fetch the blanket away in the morning—I gave it up to Butterfill and the prosecutor, who is Potts's uncle—Potts had been to me with Willis that evening with a looking-glass which they wanted to part with, but I refused buying it—I understood Potts to say it belonged to the sailor.
Potts. Q. Did you ever know me do any wrong to any one? A. No, I never knew any thing amiss of you.

GEORGE THOMAS
re-examined, I am Potts's uncle. She was not in the habit of coming to my premises—she has been two or three times, but I never asked her to sit down—these are my things (looking at them)—the pillow has not been found.

Potts's Defence. I have been for twelve months in a Union poor-house at Cambridge—I left about five weeks ago, and came to Willis, having no home, money or clothes—she offered me shelter, gave me part of what she had, and gave me money to procure cotton for my work—I showed a person my uncle's house, but did not take the property; all I took away was a feather pillow—I hope you will be lenient to me—I am sorry for what I have done—this woman is a widow, and has two children—her husband has been dead twelve months—she works from eight in the morning till six in the evening—had we not been under the influence of liquor we should not have done it.

WILLIAM THOMAS CHITTENDEN . I am a constable—I produce a certificate of Potts's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Straights office (read)- I was present at her trial at Maid stone in 1833—she is the same person.

Potts. Q. How do you know I am the same person? A. I was pre
sent and saw you tried—you were committed from Lewis ham.

Potts. You thought this would give me a little help, did you? what business had you to enter on that charge?—I suffered the law of my country for it—I robbed a good master and mistress—I hope, my Lord, my former commitment will not be against me, and that you will be as lenient as you can—I am sorry for what I have done.

POTTS—
GUILTY. * Aged 28, of stealing only.—
Transported for Seven Years.

WILLIS—
GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.

1426.
JOHN PHALAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1d., the goods of
Philip Davis, from his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . * Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1427.
JAMES JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of April, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Owen Rowland, from his person.

OWEN ROWLAND . I am a porter. On the 2nd of April I was in Greenwich fair—I felt a tug at my right-hand pocket, and missed my handkerchief from it—I saw the prisoner walking away from me, and looking confused—I took hold of him, and said, "I believe you have my handkerchief"—he said he had not—I began to search him—he would not allow me to do so—the policeman came up and found the handkerchief between his legs in his trowsers.
JAMES WILD . I am an officer. I saw the prisoner and prosecutor straggling together—I took the handkerchief out of the prisoner's trowsers—he had no pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it off the ground—I did not take it from the gentleman.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

1428.
EDWARD POTTER was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN KING . I am butler to Mr. Joseph Sladden, of Lea, in Kent. I was in the habit of sending parcels by Mrs. Walker's errand-cart—the prisoner was the servant employed—on the evening of the 26th of February, 1838, or the following morning, I paid him 3s. 6d. for parcels on his mistress's account.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure you paid it all? A. Yes, quite; I had a memorandum of it at the time—I cannot find it—it was the last sum I paid him.
Mr. CLARKSON. Q. What was the parcel? A. A portmanteau, and bag of my young master's.

FANNY WALKER . I am a widow, and carry on the business of a carrier at Eltham. In February last year the prisoner was in my service, and drove my errand-cart—He received money for parcels—I keep a book in which I enter the money received—I have it here—he should account to me for what he received on the following morning—he did not account to me for 3s. 6d. at any time from Mr. Sladden—I discharged him on the 9th of November—he gave me no account of its being unpaid—after he left my service I sent in a bill to Mr. Sladden, and found it had been paid.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was the prisoner in your service? A. Five years—he has been in the service of another carrier since I discharged him, but I have not seen him—he has been in custody about a month—I wanted to see what amount he had robbed me of before I prosecuted—this is my book—(producing it)—the entries are in my own hand-writing, and were made at the time—I never made any mistake, to my knowledge, in the accounts.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. You sent in a bill of 25s. to Mr. Sladden? A. Yes—I saw King, the butler—he could only recollect paying this 3s. 6d., but he had received altogether from him 10s. 6d.

JOHN KING
re-examined. The prosecutrix sent me a bill for 25s.—I had paid 10s. 6d. of it altogether—I recollected the 3s. 6d. directly, but I could not give a date to the other payments.

JAMES ADAMS . I am the superintendent of the Lewisham watch. I took the prisoner into custody on the 9th of March, and told him I wanted him for some money relating to Mrs. Walker's accounts—he said he knew very well what it was—that he owed her about 30s.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

1429.
THOMAS NICHOLSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a man whose name is un
known, from his person.

JAMES WESTMORLAND (police-constable F 147.) On the 1st of April I was at Greenwich fair—I saw the prisoner put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, take out a white pocket handkerchief, and put it into his own right-hand trowsers' pocket—I took him into custody, and went to inform the gentleman, but the crowd made a rush, which sent me two or three yards away, and I lost the gentleman—I do not know him—I found the hand-kerchief in the prisoner's pocket—it is marked "W. B."

Prisoner. I picked the handkerchief up, when he caught hold of my collar, and said, "You are the chap I have been looking for." Witness. I saw him put his hand into the gentleman's pocket, and take it out—it was quite clean—I found the blade of a knife in his pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1430.
JOHN FLOYD was indicted
for feloniously breaking and enter
ing the dwelling-house of
Susan Champtaloup, on the 21st of March, and stealing therein 1 cap, value 1s., her property.

SUSAN CHAMPTALOUP . I keep a shop in Bridge-street, Greenwich. On the 21st of March, about a quarter past seven o'clock in the evening, the witness M'Carthy came and gave me information, in consequence of which I missed a man's cap, which I had seen safe at five o'clock, hanging in the passage, against the parlour door—my street door was shut, and fastened with a catch-lock—it could be opened outside—you must come through the passage to get to the shop—the shop door was open—that is on the right-hand side of the passage, and the parlour door on the left.

WILLIAM THOMAS M'CARTHY . I am going on for twelve years of age. I have known the prisoner about six months—on the 21st of March, be
tween seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I went to my grandmother's, who lodges I at the prosecutrix's, and saw the prisoner, with two other boys, in the passage, taking the cap—I was standing on the stairs at the time—I had opened the street door myself and gone up—I shut the street door after me—as I went up stairs I heard somebody come in, and heard the bell ring, which hung behind the door—I looked behind me, and saw the prisoner taking the cap down—there was no light in the passage, but there was a lamp outside, and I saw him by that—I saw his face—he passed the cap down to the other boys in the passage, and they ran out into the street—I went after them, and stood and looked at them—they went by a little bow window, and tried it on—the prisoner said it would fetch 6d.—one of them stopped at the window, while the prisoner and another went with a pair of shoes into Mrs. Champtaloup's shop, and asked her if she would buy them—she said, "No"—I went and asked her if she had lost any thing, and told her what I had seen—I am quite sure I shut the door when I came in—it has a spring lock, and I heard the spring go—I am certain I put my hand to it, and felt it was fast.

DANIEL REARDON . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into cus
tody on the 21st of March, about seven o'clock in the evening, at the shop of Mr. Wolfe, in Greenwich market—he had this cap in his hand, and another lad was standing at the counter—I asked the prisoner what he was
going to do with it—he raid, "To sell it"—I asked where be got it from—he said from a lad, who was to give him 2d. to sell it for him.
ELIAS WOOLFE . I keep a shop at Greenwich. The prisoner came to me on the 21st of March, with another boy, and offered the cap for sale—the policeman came and took him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. A lad sent me to sell it out of the market, and said he would give me two pence—I went to Woolfe—I met a boy going there about a coat, and went in with him-Woolfe offered me sixpence for the cap—I did not sell it to him.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of Larceny only. Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy.
Transported for Seven Years—Isle of Wight.

1431.
RICHARD FOWLER was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
James. Davidson, on the 17th of March, putting him, in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 purse, value 3d.; 1 crown, 3 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 7 halfpence; his property.

JAMES DAVIDSON . I am a shipwright, and live at Deptford. On Sun
day morning, the 17th of March, I was at the Crown and Mason's Arms, Woolwich, having a glass of rum and milk—the prisoner was there—he was a stranger to me—I asked him to drink with me—he said he did not like rum and milk, he would sooner have beer—I called for a pot of beer, and he drank with me—we then went to the Crown and Cushion—I got some steaks, as he said he was hungry, and he partook of them—there was another man with him—we walked up the town, and came back to the house we had first been to, I think and had a pot of beer or half-and-half there—the other man did not go there with us-every thing was had at my expense—I had come over to Woolwich to see a friend-while at the public-house I had occasion to go backwards, and while in the act of looking at my money in the privy, the prisoner came in and snatched my purse out of money in the privy, the prisoner came in and snatched my ling, and three pence in copper—I said, "You are not going to rob me don't take my money"—he laughed at me, put his hand into the purse, took what he chose, returned me the purse with half-a-crown and one shilling, and went away—he had seen me with the money before I left the room—a woman came in, saying the constable was after him about some robbery, and to get out of the way—he turned out of the house-the constable came, and I gave him in charge—I we not at all tipsy—I did not give him the money to take care of—he asked me to lend him a shilling before I went into the yard, and I said I thought he had had quite sufficient without my lending him any money.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not see you at the Marquis of Granby public-house the first thing that morning, having a glass of rum-and-water? A. You might have seen me there—I was there having a glass of rum—I had two glasses of rum and milk at the Crown and Mason's Arms before you were in my company, and then a pot of beer—we then went to the Crown and Cushion, and had some half-and-half with one or two more, who you asked to drink with you, and I believe we had some rum and spruce—I do not recollect having any half-and-half at the Duke on Horseback-nor at the Standard-nor three pots of half-and-half and some gin at the

Crown—I did not give you my purse to take care of—I do not know how many persons were in the tap-room when I went into the yard—I did not say the morning after you were taken, that if I had not been tipsy I should not have given you in charge—nothing of the kind—I was not tipsy—I gave you in charge the moment I could get out of the yard you were taken close to the place.

JOSEPH BUTTERFILL . I am a constable of Woolwich. On Sunday morn
ing, the 17th of March, the prosecutor came to me—I went with him to the Duke on Horseback, but the prisoner was not there—we went to the Marquis of Gran by, and there found him—I said, "Fowler, you are my prisoner"—he said, "Your prisoner, for what?"—I said, "I will tell you when we get to the door"—when we got to the door, I told him it was for robbing a man of some money—he denied it, and said, "Let go of me, Butterfill, don't lug me through the streets in this sort of way"—I said, "Well, Dick, if you will go quietly I will let you"—I let go of him, and he walked by my side twenty or thirty yards towards the cage—be then buttoned up hi coat, stepped back, and put himself into an attitude to fight—I had great difficulty in keeping his blows off—the prosecutor who was with me, came to my assistance, and the prisoner began sparring with him—we took him to the cage, searched him, and in his jacket pocket found two half-crowns, two penny-pieces, two halfpence, a knife, and a tobacco-box—be told me that Davidson had given him the purse and money to take care of, but seeing him so free in spending the money, he (Davidson) wished it back again—Davidson appeared to have been drinking, but knew what he was about.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not say he asked me for some of it again? A. No, not some of it—you said he asked for it again.

JAMES DAVIDSON
re-examined. I have every reason to Believe this money is mine—I know the prisoner had no money while I was in his company, for he asked me to lend him a shilling.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not tell you I had 18d. of my own? A. No—I lent you the tobacco-box to take a pipe of tobacco from—I do not accuse you of stealing that.

(The prisoner in his defence stated that the prosecutor had been to a great number of public-houses with him, drinking; and being very much intoxi
cated, had given him his money to take care of for him.)
NOT GUILTY .

1432.
JAMES PEW and
HENRY JONES were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
James Clamp, from his person.

JAMES CLAMP . I was at Greenwich fair on Tuesday, the 2nd of April, standing, looking at a show—a witness told me my pocket was picked—I turned round and saw both the prisoners in custody of Dyke—I went op to them, and saw my handkerchief drop from under Pew's coat, which was buttoned up—it fell down in front of him—I saw his hand up at his coat at the time it fell—Dyke took it up—I had felt in my pocket, and missed it as soon as the man spoke to me—I knew it to be mine directly I saw it Pew. Q. Did you see my hand in your pocket? A. No, but I saw the hand-kerchief drop from your coat—I did not tell the Magistrate I saw it in your hand—I said, in the officer's hand—I said it was in the prisoner's hand, but immediately corrected myself, and said it was in the officer's hand.

WILLIAM DYKE . I saw the prosecutor at the fair, standing, looking at Richardson's show—the prisoners were behind him, close to him—I saw Pew speak to Jones, and saw Pew take the handkerchief from the prose
cutor's pocket in about two minutes—I had not seen Jones do any thing, but he was in company with Pew—I took Pew into custody directly, and the handkerchief dropped from under his coat—I had lost sight of him for a moment—I took it up, and told him I wanted him for stealing the hand
kerchief from the prosecutor—he said he knew nothing about it, it must have been put under his coat—I am sure he took it—I saw his hand in the pocket—I took them both into custody, with assistance.

Pew. The other witness told him, and he came and collared me. Wit
ness. A young man had called my attention to them—I had watched them for ten minutes.

Jones. Q. What distance were you behind when you saw Pew speak to me? A. Close to you—I did not tell the Magistrate I was some dis
tance behind—there was nobody behind you at all—I told the Magistrate I saw you speak together.

COURT. Q. Did you not say before the Magistrate, "I am quite sure Jones attempted to pick the prosecutor's pocket, I saw him do so?" A. No—that is a mistake on the Magistrate's part in the deposition, not on my part.

GEORGE RANDALL . I am a labourer. I was at Greenwich fair on the 2nd of April, in front of Richardson's show, standing behind Clamp—the two prisoners came up in company together, pushed me away, and pushed in between me and Clamp—I saw Jones wink at Pew, and Jones put his hand to Clamp's pocket to feel it—I watched them a few moments, and seeing they intended to pick the pocket, I turned my head to look for an officer—I went and spoke to Dyke, and went to my place again behind the prosecutor—I saw Pew try to pick the pocket, but he did not do so then Jones was standing close to his side—I stood a few moments longer, and then saw Pew draw the handkerchief out of Clamp's pocket, make a rush on one side, and shove it up his coat—the officers then collared them, and 1 informed Clamp.

Jones. Q. Are you positive you saw us come up there together? A. Yes—the crowd was quite thin when you came up—I saw you attempt the pocket—I was standing close behind you, and could see your arms and hands, and I made a stoop down to look.
Pew. Q. Did not you tell the Magistrate Jones took the handkerchief; and gave it to me? A. No.

Pew's Defence. I am a poor man out of work—going along I saw some
thing like a fair—I went, and stood there with my hands in my pocket looking over the prosecutor's shoulder—there was a great shove and pushing about—I was nearly pushed over another man—I felt a hand go up my coat, but who it was and what they put there I could not see—and before I could do so the policeman charged me with this.
Jones's Defence. It is impossible the witness could have seen me attempt the man's pocket through two persons standing close together—I never saw Pew before.

PEW*—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Fifteen Years. JONES—
NOT GUILTY .

1433.
ELIZABETH WOOTTEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 gown, value 3s.; and 1 blanket, value 2s.; the goods of
Tho
mas Wootten.
MARIA WOOTTEN . I am the wife of Thomas Wootten, a Greenwich pensioner—the prisoner is my husband's son's wife, and lived with us for nothing—her husband did not live with her—he allowed her 3s. a week About half-past five o'clock last Monday morning I went out to work leaving my gown and blanket at home—I returned at half-past seven o'clock in the evening, and missed them—I never allowed the prisoner to pawn them.

EDWARD CARTER . I am a pawnbroker at Greenwich. On Monday, the 8th of April, the prisoner pledged this gown and blanket with me—not both at the same time—I believe she pledged the blanket first, the gown next, and she came a third time for more money on the gown—she pledged them in her own name—I knew her very well—I believe a woman named Cook was with her when she pledged the gown.

ROBERT DUNN (police-constable R 9.) I received information last Monday, and found the prisoner at a house in Queen-street, Greenwich—I told her I took her on suspicion of stealing a gown and blanket—she said she knew nothing at all about it, it was the first she had heard of it—on our way to the station-house I told her I knew where the gown was—she said, "I know where it is too, but the other woman knew nothing at all about it, for I pawned it myself'—I said, "If you pawned them you must know where the duplicates are"—she said, "I have got them here, here they are"—they were pinned to her gown under her shawl—I took them from her, and produce them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I did not pledge the gown—it was the prosecntrix's son, because his mother had locked up the tea and sugar, and he could not get any breakfast—he pledged it for 8d., and I went and got 10d. more on it afterwards—I pledged the blanket myself, and the boy was with me at the time.

EDWARD CARTER
re-examined. I am sure it was the prisoner pledged them—the boy had pledged the gown before—I have no recollection of seeing him that day—I will not positively say he was not there—I am po
sitive I saw the prisoner twice about the gown, and she had two separate payments on it—the last payment was in the evening—I cannot say the boy did not pledge it—I am positive the prisoner pledged the blanket—she has been with the boy when he has pledged the gown before.
MRS. WOOTTEN re-examined. I have sent my son to pawn the gown several times before, but I never knew that the prisoner went with him.
NOT GUILTY .

1434.
ANN HEARN was indicted
for unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously assaulting
Thomas Hearn, on the 24th of March, and cutting and wounding him upon his face and left cheek, with intent to maim and disable him.—2nd COUNT, stating her intent to be to him some grievous bodily harm.

THOMAS HEARN . I am a labourer, and live in Mill-lane, Deptford—the prisoner is my wife. On Sunday, the 24th of March, about twelve o'clock, I went home to my lodging—I had been drinking at a public-house

in Broadway, Deptford, and was very much intoxicated—my wife was not at home when I got there—when she came in, I began to quarrel with her, through a little jealousy—I accused her of having been drinking with a young man—we came to high words and blows—I struck her and she struck me—we both had a fight together—I was striking a light, and it went out—the candlestick was on the floor, and the candle smashed—I do not know whether the wind blew it out, or whether I and my wife knocked it out—I have given an account of this before—it fell, and went out—I do not know whether I put it out or my wife, for I was very much in liquor—we both had a quarrel together and blows—something struck me on my left arm—I found my face was cut, and ran up stairs for assistance—there were people in the house—I do not know what my arm was cut by—there was no one in the room but our two selves—I must have struck her first, for I am very bad when I am in liquor—I am sure I struck her first, coming in at the door—I think I called her bad names—I did not perceive my hand scratched in the dark—I did not feel the blood before the people told me up stairs that my hand was bleeding.

Prisoner, He caught me by the hair of my head, and threw me on the bed, while I had the knife in my hand. Witness, Very likely I might have done it—I know I was wicked enough to do it—I did not do it to my knowledge, but I was very much in liquor, and do not recollect any thing about it at all—there had been some meat and bread on the table—I did not see any then—I did not see any knife in her hand before the light wat blown out.

Prisoner. Q. Was not I cutting some wood for the fire at the time of the quarrel? A. I saw her cutting some wood, and recollect throw
ing her down on the ground—both of us were down on the ground—some crockery-ware was broken, and we were fighting amongst it—I do not know about her cutting wood—I accused her wrongfully, and pulled her in-doort—I went to work two days afterwards—I have only had the wound dressed two or three times—I was at work two days afterwards in the rain.

WILLIAM MARSHALL (police-constable R 187.) I was on duty in Broad-way, Deptford, between twelve and one o'clock on Sunday night, or Mon
day morning, the 24th, and heard cries of as Police," in Mill-lane—I went down the lane, and met the prosecutor, led by a young man—he appeared to be severely wounded—his face was cut—he was holding his hand to his face—it was bleeding profusely—I directed he should be taken to the station-house, and got surgical assistance—I went with another policeman in search of the prisoner, and found her concealed among some timber and bricks, on the premises of Mr. Mackey, the engineer, adjoining the house where this happened—there is a fence separating the two premises, but that was broken down—it was at the back of the house—she said she had done it, and was quite willing to die, provided she could see him die before her—she did not mention any thing about the gallows—this is my hand-writing—(looking at his deposition)—I believe it was read over to me before I signed it—we searched the room where they were, and my sergeant found this knife, concealed on a shelf in the cupboard—as soon as it was produced she said that was the knife she did it with.

WILLIAM CROXON (police-sergeant R 20.) On Monday morning, about twenty minutes before one o'clock, I was on duty in Mill-ane—I heard a wrangling from a house up a turning in the lane where the prosecutor and his wile lodged—I saw the prosecutor take a light from the policeman

at the gate—that was directly after I heard the wrangling—he then went in-doors—I remained at the end of the alley—Hearn came out again and asked for a light, as he said Nancy had put it out—I went back with him, and heard the prisoner say, "You b I should like to cut your b throat"—the door was shut—I said "Open the door; are you not ashamed of making use of such language on Sunday night?" Hearn was outside with me—she let him in—I begged of Hearn not to quarrel, and to have no more words—I shut the window-shutter to, being outside, and Hearn fastened it within—about ten minutes afterwards I was in the Fountain yard, about five hundred yards off, and in conse
quence of what Marshall told me, I went with him to apprehend the prisoner—I found her in Mr. Mackey's yard, about one hundred and fifty yards from the house—Marshall found her at the furthest corner of the yard—there was a quantity of fellies and pieces of timber, to conceal her, and a cart likewise—she had hid herself—she could not be seen without going up to the timber, and looking among it—I afterwards found the knife on a shelf in the cupboard—I think it was the top-shelf—di
rectly I produced it I said, "Is this the knife?"—she said "Yes"—I did not hear distinctly what she said when Marshall took her, not so at to state any particular word.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I come out and say, "I am here, if I have done any thing wrong, I am ready to go with you?" A. She would not come out when Marshall went to where she was, not before he discovered her—she said, "I will go with you"—that was when she was close to me—the cupboard had no door, it was a recess with shelves—I have the shirt here which Hearn had on.

EDWARD DOWNING . I am a surgeon of Deptford. Sergeant Croxon brought Hearn to my house, between one and two o'clock on Monday morning—I examined him—he was bleeding very profusely—he had a wound on his left cheek, about five inches and a half in length, in a half circle, going from the ear to the mouth—one part of it at the middle was to the bone—it was not generally deep—I applied pressure to stop the hemorrhage—being early in the morning I was very much fatigued, having been up the whole night before, and with great difficulty I stopped it—about seven o'clock the same morning the prosecutor called me up again, and I was then obliged to make use of ligatures, as it was bleeding afresh—he was faint—I was obliged to give him a stimulant while I was dressing it—it was certainly a dangerous wound, and if it had been a little lower, I think it would have been fatal—it appeared to be inflicted by a sharp in
strument—the knife produced was likely to have done it—I consider it dangerous, if it had not been attended to immediately—he is convalescent, and there is not any fear now.

Prisoner's Defence. After I went home, he began to ill-use me, and caught hold of me by the hair of my head, and tore all my hair out on one side—I had the knife in my hand, having been cutting some wood with it to lay for fire in the morning—he chucked me on the bed, and got his two hands round my neck, trying to choke me—as I was trying to get up again in the struggle, I cut him about the face with the knife, but did nut intend to do so.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Two Years.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1435.
THOMAS DUNN was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 adze, value 2s. 8d.; 1 chisel, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas White; and 31/2lbs. weight of nails, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
the London and Greenwich Railway Company; to which he pleaded
GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1436.
MARY WILKINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of March, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William John Mug
geridge.

ELIZABETH MUGGERIDGE . I am the wife of William John Muggeridge, who keeps the Duke of Sussex, in New-street, Deptford. The prisoner was an occasional servant to me—I missed a silk handkerchief on the 26th of March—this is it.
JAMES BUCHANAN . I am assistant to a pawnbroker at Deptford. The prisoner pledged this handkerchief on the 26th of March.
ALFRED HAMMOND (police-constable R 79.) I took the prisoner—she said she stole the handkerchief, and pledged it in the Broadway.
Prisoner's Defence. I pawned it, not with an intention to Keep it, but to get it out the same night—the policeman came to me and said, "You tell me, and I will get you clear."
ALFRED HAMMOND . I did not say any thing of the kind.
NOT GUILTY .

1437.
WILLIAM BURFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 1 ink-glass, value 6d.; 1 stick of sealing-wax, value 1d.; 1/2 an ounce of wafers, value 1d.; 3 pens, value 1d.; and 1 box, value 4s., the goods of
William Rawlinson.
SUSAN RAWLINSON . I am the wife of William Rawlinson—I kept a stall at Greenwich-fair. On the 3rd of April, I lost a rose-wood box, with an ink-glass, sealing-wax, and wafers in it—this is it.

ROBERT BRODIE (police-constable L 132.) I was at the fair, and saw the prisoner in company with two thieves—the prisoner had an apron on—he sidled up to the prosecutor's stall, took the box, and put it under his apron—I stopped him with it—he said he did not take it, the other boys did.

Prisoner's Defences Another boy took it.
GUILTY . * Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

1438.
ELIZABETH ANN HILLIER was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of March, 1 candlestick, value 1s., and 1 brush, value 6d., the goods of
John King; and that she had been before convicted of felony; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Confined One Year.

1439.
HENRY JONES,
HENRY UGE , and
JOHN WILKINS , were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March, 6 pairs of leather half-fronts for boots, value 9s., the goods of
Henry Crossley.

JAMES CROSSLEY . I am the son of Henry Crossley, of Church-street, Deptford. On the 26th of March, the three prisoners came to his shop Jones came in first for a pair of leather half-fronts, and while he was looking at them, Uge came in and bought some small articles which came to 3d. or 4d., which he paid for, and went out—as soon as he went out Wilkins came for some things which came to 8 1/2 d—he paid, and as soon

as he went Jones paid half-a-crown for a pair of fronts, and went away—I then put the fronts away, and thought some were missing—I went to the door and saw the three prisoners together—I spoke to a policeman—they saw me and ran away—they turned into Effingham-place, and one of them threw a bag down—we followed them, I suppose a mile, and took all three of them in the Creek-road—a boy took up the bag, and I gave it to the policeman—it contained eleven pairs of half-fronts—six pairs of them belonged to my father.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has your father any partner? A. No—I will undertake to say that Wilkins was in the shop while Jones was there—he bought some hand shank, and a quarter of a yard of Union, which came to 81/2d.—I am certain he did not buy any thing else—Uge and him were not in the shop together—I never said they were—Wilkins paid me with a half-crown, and had 1s. 91/2d. change—I observed nothing about him.

JAMES GATES (police-constable R 144.) I had a communication from Crossley—the prisoners were all three running together—I ran and followed them till they ran out of my sight—I understood which way they went, and cut a nearer way—I met them in the Creek-road—Wilkins then ran from the other two—I pursued and took him in the Stowage—I did not see the bag till I took them to the station-house—I then had it from Mr. Crossley.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where did you see them first? A. In Church-street, about one hundred and fifty yards from the prose
cutor's shop—I cannot say whether either of them had a bag at that time—they are the same parties that had passed me before Mr. Crossley spoke to me.

WILLIAM JAMES MORGAN . I am the son of the Deptford carrier. About twelve o'clock on the 26th of March, I was at the corner of Effing
ham-place—I saw a cart there, and a man putting a horse in it—these three men ran by—one of them threw a blue bag away, and it lodged in the cart—this is the bag—I can swear to it—it was like this bag—I ran after the mob—I did not pick it up.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Howmany were in the mob? A. About forty were following after them.

COURT to JAMES CROSSLEY. Q. Who found the bag? A. The boy showed me where it was, and I took it out of a coal cart which was stand
ing at the corner of Effingham-place.
GEORGE WILSON (police-constable R 179.) Uge was given into my custody—I found on him what he had bought at the shop.

NATHANIEL LEIGH . I do not live with the prosecutor, but the pri
soners Jones and Wilkins came to my master's shop before this day.
JOSEPH HALL . The three prisoners were at my father's shop on the Saturday before.

(William Cannon, shoemaker, and James Marriott, hair-dresser, of Blue Anchor-yard, gave Uge a good character; Barnett Quin, butcher, of Stoney-lane; Edward Ferne, carpenter, Swan-street, Minories; and Abraham Green, gave Jones a good character.) JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

UGE*—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

Transported for Seven Years. WILKINS—
GUILTY . Aged 22.
(There was another indictment against Jones and Wilkins.)

1440.
MARIA FORSTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of March, 1 purse, value 6d.; 3 sovereigns, and 3 shillings, the goods and monies of
Joseph Reading, from his person.

JOSEPH READING . I am an engineer. I am fifty-seven years old—I went to Woolwich on Good Friday morning—I had something to eat, and got too much drink—I was coming home, and turned down the lane by New Cross—the prisoner followed me—we went down the lane together—I missed my purse, in which I had three sovereigns and some silver, from my left hand pocket—I had seen the money safe a little before I went down the lane—I was rather disguised in liquor—I told the prisoner she had robbed me—she said she had not touched me, nor touched my pros perty—this is my purse, it has three sovereigns in it.
Prisoner. You asked me to go down the lane. Witness. I did not—we had not been drinking for three hours together—the policeman was not coming after me for passing a bad sixpence.

JOHN ROSCOE (police-constable R 119.) I was on duty near New Cross—I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner walk down Five Bell-lane—I fol
lowed, and when I got near them, the prosecutor told me she had robbed him of his purse and money—the prisoner said, "I have neither seen purse nor money, so help me God"—I took her to the station-house.
MART WALKER . I am searcher at the station-house, I found this purse and money concealed on the prisoner's person.
Prisoner's Defence, I was walking down the lane—he fell down, and was very tipsy—he had this purse in his hand—I helped him up, and he dropped it into my hand.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1441.
THOMAS POPKINS,
EDWARD COOK , and
THOMAS CASSIDY , were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April, 110lbs. weight of iron, value 5s., the goods of
the London and Greenwich Railway Com
pany.

MARY ANN SMITH . I am the wife of Charles Smith, and live in Church-street, Deptford, and deal in marine stores. On the 2nd of April, the pri
soners came to my house together—each one brought a bar of iron—they appeared to me to belong to the rail-road—I asked whose iron it was—they said Mr. Cook's—I said if Mr. Cook came himself I would buy it—they told me that Mr. Cook was outside—they went to call him and ran away, leaving the iron in my shop—the policeman came and took it next morn
ing.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure there was not one outside? A. Yes, they were all inside.

JAMES BARRBLL (police-sergeant R 8.) From information I apprehended Popkins on Friday morning—I asked him who the others were who were with him, when he took the iron to Mrs. Smith's—he said Cook and Cus
tody, and he should not have taken it if they had not persuaded him.

THOMAS WATSON . I am an officer of the London and Greenwich Rail-road Company. I have the Act of Parliament constituting the Company here—I have seen this iron, it is ours—there is but one other rail-road that has a rail of this description—theirs is a quarter of an inch lower than this.

The document produced by the witness as the Act of Parliament, not having the name of the Queen's printer affixed, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

1442.
CHARLES MONK was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 130lbs. weight of lead, value 10s., the goods of
Pelham Richardson; and fixed to a certain building; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Five Days, and
Whipped.

1443.
ANN CARR was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April, 121/2lbs. weight of butter, value 10s.; 1 1/2 lb. weight of bacon, value 1s.; 111/2lbs. weight of cheese, value 2s. 2d.; and 9 eggs, value 6d.; the goods of
John Nelson, her master: and
JOHN MOORE
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Sta
tute, &c.

WILLIAM CROWLEY (police-constable R 178.) In consequence of in
formation, I went, on the 5th of April, about a quarter-past six o'clock in the morning, and placed myself near Mr. Nelson's house—I stood at the top of New King-street, Deptford—I saw the prisoner Moore come down Broomfield-place with a basket in his hand—he turned down Old Kings street, and stopped at the back door of Mr. Nelson's premises—he re
mained there about a minute or two—I saw the gate opened, and he went into the yard—I went and stood two or three yards below the gate—I could not see into the yard—I remained two or three minutes, when I saw the gate opened—Moore came out with a basket in one band, and a small bundle in the other—(the front of Mr. Nelson's shop was not open at that time)—Moore saw me, and appeared very much confused—he turned round, and walked into the yard again quickly—I followed, and about t yard inside the gate I took him by the arm, and told him, from informa
tion I had received, I should take him into custody on suspicion of rob
bing Mr. Nelson—the female prisoner was standing about a yard from him at the time—they both appeared very much confused—on the way to the station-house, Moore repeatedly begged me to let him go, if not, it would ruin him—he said the things were given him by a female—the bas
ket contained twelve pounds and a half of butter, and the bundle a Dutch cheese, a piece of Gloucester cheese about half a pound, a piece of bacon weighing about a pound and a half, and in his great-coat pocket were nine eggs, which he took out—I went to Mr. Nelson's house—Mr. Nelson and and I went to Moore's lodgings, and, in a cupboard in a room occupied by Moore, I found a small piece of Cheshire cheese, which Mr. Nelson identified—about nine o'clock the same morning I took Carr in Pleasant-row—she told me she had given the things to Moore.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Carr is sister to the prose
cutor, is not she? A. I believe she is his sister-in-law—the prosecutor's back gate is in Old King-street—it opens into the yard which is connected with the houses—I saw Moore go into the yard, and he remained there two or three minutes at furthest—I cannot say whether he entered the house—I could not see him in the yard, as the gate was shut.

JOHN NELSON . I am a cheese monger, and live in New King-street, Deptford. Carr is my wife's sister, and was in my service—on the morn
ing of the 5th of April the policeman came to my house before I was up—in consequence of what he said I went to Moore's house, and found some eggs in the cupboard, twelve in a basin and two in a dish; three small pieces of cheese weighing about half a pound, and nearly a pound of butter in a plate—I had cheese resembling what I found, but I could not swear

it was mine—there is a door between my shop and the parlour, which has no lock on it, but it is always shut at night—my butter was kept in the shop—I believe the butter found on the prisoner Moore to be mine, and I have more Dutch cheese similar to this one found on Moore—I cannot say that I missed butter, as my stock is large, and I have a son who ma
nages my business—I am sometimes out for two or three hours—Carr had been with me sixteen years—I never saw Moore in my house—he has been to the door to inquire for Carr—I understood he paid his addresses to her.
Cross-examined. Q. You have a wife alive, I suppose? A. Yes, and I have a son in the business—I believe the butter to be mine—I have some of the same kind—I have not missed any cheese or eggs.

CARR—
GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined One Month.

MOORE.
NOT GUILTY .

1444. The said
JOHN MOORE
was subsequently indicted for steal
ing, on the 5th of April, 12 1/2lbs. weight of butter, value 10s.; 1 1/2lb. weight of cheese, value 2s. 6d.; and 9 eggs, value 6d.; the goods of
John Nelson; on which the same evidence was given as in the former case.

GUILTY . Aged 55.—
Confined Six Months.

1445.
HENRY PALMER and
RICHARD HALL were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

MESSRS. BODKIN and DOAN I conducted the Prosecution. THOMAS HAWES WARREN. I keep a chandler's-shop, in Carrterbury-plaee, Old Kent-road. On the 16th of March, about four o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner Hall came into my shop-for one penny-worth of tobacco—he put down a bad shilling—I tried it, and it was bad—I bit it, and bent it, and gave it to him back—he went away—I directed two of my sons to follow him, and tell a policeman.

THOMAS WARREN . I am the prosecutor's son. My father told me to go after Hall—my brother was with me—when Hall got as for as the Crown and Anchor public-house, he crossed the road, and then threw a tobacco pipe at Palmer, and another man, who got away—they walked on some distance, and then the other one went into a baker's shop—I went into the baker's—I did not see the prisoners taken.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you hear the other's name? A. Smith was the name he gave at the station-house.

ROBERT WARRBN . I went out with my brother to watch Hall—he went on towards the Crown and Anchor—I then saw Palmer, and the other man—they approached together, and went on talking about 200 yards, then the other left them, and went into a baker's shop, and the two prisoners went on on the other side of the way—when the little one came out of the baker's shop, he went on eating a roll—he went on the same side as the baker's—he did not join the prisoners again—my brother sent me on to follow Hall and Palmer—I did so, and saw three policemen—I told them something, and they went in pursuit of the prisoners—when the policeman had been spoken to, I saw Palmer look round, and then run—Hall ran after him—they ran in the same direction, and as they ran I saw Hall hold up his hand, and throw something over Mr. Cormack's garden-wall—there is a little bend in the wall there, and it was close at the bend that he threw it.

JOHN ROSCOE (police-constable R 119.) I met this witness, and in consequence of what he said, I and the policemen went in pursuit of the prisoners—while they were running I saw Palmer pass some-thing to Hall—it appeared to he something in a white paper—I then called, "Stop thief,"—a gentleman collared Hall, and I saw Hall hold up his hand, as if to throw something over the wall—I did not see any thing thrown—I pursued, and took the prisoners—I found on Hall three farthings and a tobacco-box.

Cross-examined. Q. Must you not have seen if there had been any thing thrown? A. I was running very swiftly, and perhaps I did not take particular notice—I observed him put up his arm—I saw Palmer look back before they began to run—Hall might have thrown something away, and I not see it.

JAMES ERRINGTON . I am a laborer, and live at Peck ham. I was re
turning from Greenwich, on the evening of the 16th of March—I was opposite Mr. Cormack's wall, and heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw the two prisoners running—Palmer was rather a-head of Hall—some gentleman tried to stop Hall, and I saw Hall pull his hand out of his right hand-pocket, and throw some shillings over the wall—I saw them scale over the wall—they ran about fifty yards further, and were stopped.
JOSEPH WILLIAM CLARK (police-constable R 99.) In consequence of what a gentleman said to me, I went through Mr. Cormack's gate, searched behind the wall, and picked up these twelve shillings.
GEORGE PEDDER (police-constable R 108.) I searched the same spot, and found five more shillings.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to her Majesty's Mint—these seventeen shillings are all counterfeit, and all cast in the same mould.

PALMER—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

HALL—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1446.
JAMES MITCHELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of March, 1 copper, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Braine, and fixed to a certain building: to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1447.
WILLIAM LAKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of April, 1 plane, value 2s., the goods of
John Griffith Randall; and 1 plane, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Frederick Iles.

JOHN GRIFFITH RANDALL . I am a carpenter. I lost my plane from a shop in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich, on the 10th of April, while I went to dinner—the front doors of the shop were fastened, but there was a side-door which was not fastened, only shut to—the prisoner had worked, the day before as a sawyer, but not that day—this is my plane.
FREDERICK ILES . I left my plane there, and missed it—this is it.
JOHN LOVICK . I am a pawnbroker. I took in these two planes of the prisoner.
WALTER CHAMBERS (police-constable R 48.) I took the prisoner. He denied this at first—then he said he pawned them, and gave me the duplicate.

GUILTY . Aged—29.
Confined Three Months.

1448.
THOMAS HOY was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of April, 4 pairs of boots, value 1l. 2s., the goods of
William Freeman.

WILLIAM FREEMAN . I am a shoemaker, and live in Greenwich-road. I was sitting in my back parlour on the 10th of April, and in consequence of something ray wife told me I ran out of doors—I saw the prisoner rather running—I pursued him, and took hold of his collar—I said, what have you been taking? and at that moment I saw a boot fall from his person—I took it up, and with the boot and the prisoner I proceeded towards the station-house—Mr. Judson my neighbour came up—I wished him to go and see if there were not some more boots—be said, "If you will go I will hold the boy"—I went back, and close to where the prisoner had been standing when I took him, I found seven more boots—they were all mine.

JOHN JUDSON . I am a licensed victualler. T was standing at my door cleaning a bird-cage—I saw the prisoner running along—I ran after him with the prosecutor—I saw one boot drop from the prisoner—I took him to the station-house.
Prisoner's Defence. I went up the gateway, and the gentleman came and said, "Have yon stolen any thing?" I said, "No"—he took me op the gateway and found the boot.

GUILTY . * Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1449.
MARY RHODA JONES was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

ELEANOR MART ELIZABETH LOCKER . I am the wife of Edward William Locker; he is one of the Commissioners of Greenwich Hospital. On the 31st of December the prisoner called at my house—she was quite a stran
ger—she stated that her husband was transported, and she was very anxious to join him—that a ship was lying at Gravesend, and her children were on board, and she was very anxious to raise money to go there—she showed me this card, which she said had been given her by the owners of the ship, and it was to sail very shortly—seeing the card I believed her story, and gave her a crown and some trifling articles—she did not give me the card, bat laid it down and forgot it—I found it after she left.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE.Q. Have you kept the card ever since? A. No, I sent it to Mr. Gordon—if this is not the card she produced, it is so like it that I cannot tell the difference—I read it while she was there-rand after she left, and kept it till I sent it to Mr. Gordon—I gave the prisoner a crown-piece as an act of charity and humanity, supposing what she said was correct.

JAMES BRODIE GORDON . I am a merchant, and live in Leaden hall-street. I am owner of the vessel called the Mary Ann—I remember see
ing the prisoner, I think it was in October last—the Mary Ann sailed for Hobart Town in November, Henry Marshall was commander—the prisoner called a week or ten days before it sailed—she said she came from a Mr. Palliser, a gentleman on Fins bury-pavement—she wanted a passage to Hobart Town, and as I had a ship sailing he had sent her to me—she stated a pitiful case to me—said her husband was on the other side, and she was very desirous to go with her two children to him—she asked the fare, I said it would be 60l. or 70l.; but as she told me such a story I

would put it at one-half of that, and she should go in a cabin by herself and her two children for 35l.—I gave her this card—she said she would go and get the money, that she had got 24l. in the hand of a friend in the City, and she would bring me that in the course of a quarter of an hour—I told her the vessel would sail in a few days, and it was then lying in the London Docks—I did not see her again—her children were never on board the vessel to my knowledge—the next I heard of her was by a letter from Mrs. Locker inclosing this card, which I had given the prisoner—the ship was at Gravesend one day, on her passage.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you receive this letter from Mrs. Locker per
sonally? A. No, by post—I had no other vessel beside the Mary Ann going that month—I had a vessel sailed in January to Sydney, not to Hobart Town.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Have you got the letter you received which in closed the card? A. Yes—I had no conversation with the prisoner about any other vessel than the Mary Ann.
MRS. LOCKER. This is the letter I sent to Mr. Gordon with the card In closed.

ALICE YOUNG . The prisoner lived in the same house that I do in James-street, New-cut, Lambeth, from September till she was taken in custody—a man of the name of Thompson lived in the same place with her—she had two children, who went to school with my little girl—they are now in Lambeth workhouse—I don't know what has become of Thompson.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever hear of her having a husband trans
ported? A. I have heard the children say so.

WILLIAM HORSFORD . I am constable to the Mendicity Society—I have known the prisoner about four years—I was sent for by the inspector on the 7th or 8th of March—the prisoner was then in custody on another charge.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you examined before the Magistrates? A. No, I was ordered to attend here—I don't know any thing of this case.
(The prisoner delivered in a petition for a lenient sentence, stating herself to be in a destitute state.)

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1450.
FRANCES BUTCHER was indicted
for forging and uttering a receipt for the sum of 8s. 5d., with intent to defraud
George Field;
also for stealing, on the 14th of February, 3 sovereigns, and 8d. in copper, the money of
George Field, her master; to both of which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1451.
WILLIAM BRAGG was indicted
for embezzlement.

MARY ANN DOWLEY . I am the wife of William Edward Downey, a baker, at Upper Tooting. The prisoner lived with us about twelve months as journeyman—he was entrusted to receive money on his masters account for bread which he took out—he ought to account for the money he received the same day—he did not account for the receipt of any
money on the 28th of March from Mrs. Newbury, who is a customer of ours—we had suspicions the night he received this 8s.—he was asked for it, and denied having it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was your husband unwell? A. Yes—the prisoner did not manage the business—he did not make the bread—he ought to have paid the 8s. on Thursday—he was taken in custody on the Saturday—there was a balance of 3s. 6d. then due to him, not a week's wages—he was not in the habit of deducting his wages from the money he received—I was not always present when he settled with my husband—he was going away a month before, and we increased his wages 1s. a-week, I think, to stay.

CHARLOTTE NEWBURT . I live at Lower Tooting. I dealt with the prosecutor for bread which the prisoner brought—on the 28th of March I paid him 8s. on his master's account, between twelve and one o'clock in the day—he receipted the bill—it was 9s., but there was a mistake in it of 1s., which he took off.

WILLIAM PEARSON . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner at the prosecutor's house, on Saturday the 30th of March—I told told I took him for receiving Mrs. Newbury's bill—he said he had received it, and if his master would allow him a little time, he would contrive to make the money up.

JURY to MRS. DOWLEY. Q. Do you know whether he had received say other money on his master's account the same day as the 8s.? A. Not to my knowledge—we had overlooked other things which he had committed before?
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 21. —Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

1452.
JAMES JEFFRIES was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Bond, at Bermondsey, about the hour of three in the night of the 1st of March, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 1 printed book, value 4s.; 2 snuff-boxes, value 15s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 4s.; 1 table-doth, value 1s.; 1 frock, value 2s.; and 1 pair of gloves, value 6d. his goods.

HARRIET BOND . I am the wife of Henry Bond of George's-terrace, Grimscott-street, Bermondsey. On Friday, the 1st of March, I was the last person up—I went to bed at twelve o'clock—I examined the house, and it was all fast—I locked the kitchen window—the shutters were not closed—that window looks against a dead wall on the back premises, and it about two yards from the wall—I was disturbed about three o'clock, as my youngest girl was taken ill, and crying, and the dog was barking—I did not go down stairs then—I heard nothing more particular in the night—I got up soon after six o'clock next morning, went down into the kitchen, and found the window-sash half open, and a pane of glass over the fastening broken—it was whole and fastened the night before—a person could put something through the broken pane to open the fastening, but the space was not large enough to admit a hand through—the sash could then be lifted up—I went into the front parlour, and missed "Burkitt's Notes on the New Testament," a pair of shoes, a pair of gloves, a silk handkerchief,

and two snuff-boxes—one was a painted one, and the other embossed with the Holy Family on the lid—I missed from the kitchen a table-cloth a sheet, and a child's frock—I had seen them all safe the evening before.

HENRY NOAKES . I live with my mother in Unicorn-square, Tooley. street I hawk papers about, and do any thing I can get—I know the prisoner—on Saturday, the 2nd of March, between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, I saw him at the Eight Bells and Anchor public-house in Bermondsey-street—he showed me a book, a kind of Testament, and asked me to pledge it for him—I opened it, and saw no hard names in it as I had always seen in Matthew—I pawned it at Mr. Rosier's in Tooley. street for 2s.—I gave the prisoner the money and the duplicate—be said I was better known at the shop than him, and he would stand a pint of beer if I did—he gave me a share of a pint of beer.

HENRY NEWSTEAD . I am shopman to Mr. Rosier, a pawnbroker, in Tooley-street. I produce a book which was pawned by Noakes on the 2nd of March—it is "Burkitt on the New Testament"—the first page of Mat
they is out—I have also some sleeves and a frock, pawned by the prisoner on the afternoon of the 2nd of March for 4s., also a sheet, a shirt, and a pair of shoes at the same time.
