Prisoner. Q. Did you not say at the office you could not swear to me? A. That was respecting a silk pelisse which was pawned—I an positive you pawned these things.

GEORGE HAVILL (police-sergeant M 2.) I took the prisoner in charge on the 5th of March at the Surrey theatre. I took him to the station-house—I searched him, and found a silk handkerchief round his neck, a pair of gloves in his pocket, and a snuff-box—he said he gave 3d. for the snuff-box, the gloves he had had eighteen months, and the silk handker
chief was well known to be his own—Noakes was present when I appre
hended him—I asked the prisoner how he came in possession of the book he gave Noakes to pawn—he said he gave 1s. 3d. or 1s. 6d. for it to a sailor, who had gone to Gravesend.

WILLIAM WILKINS (police-constable R 11.) I went to the station-house and took off the prisoner's shoes, having observed footmarks in Mr. Bond's back premises—I compared the shoes with the footmarks which I had covered over to preserve them, and they corresponded—I made an im
pression by the side of the footmark—the ground was soft—there were nails in the shoes and also in the impression.
Prisoner. The nails in the shoes could not make any Impression—they are so worn. Witness, They are not worn down so much as the prisoner states.
Prisoner, He said at the cell of the office that I must have worn them a great deal since the robbery. Witness, I did not say a word of the sot.

GEORGE HAVILL
re-examined. I was at the cell of the office—there was no such conversation passed.

MRS. BOND re-examined. This is our Testament—here is a misprint which my husband corrected, in my presence—this snuff-box and these gloves are ours—they are the gloves the prisoner was wearing—this hand-kerchief which he wore, is ours—this child's frock is mine, and was worn that day by my child—this sheet was taken out of the kitchen—the table-cloth and one snuff-box have not been found.
Prisoner's Defence, I was going to my master's house on Saturday evening, to see if I might return to work, as he had discharged me—I

passed the Eight Bells, and as I came back, about one o'clock, I met a young sailor chap, with a book and other things in his hand—he asked me to buy it—I gave him 18d. for the book, and 3d. for a snuff-box—we went into a public-house, and had a pint of four penny ale—on the Sunday morning he met me, and said he would sell me the duplicate of a handker
chief—I said I did not wish to have it—I met him again on Monday morning, and bought the ticket of him—I gave him 1s. 3d. to get it out, and wore it, and afterwards he gave me the gloves.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.
(There were other indictments against the prisoner.)

1453.
CATHERINE DENNY was indicted
for unlawfully, malici
ously, and feloniously, assaulting
Bridget Santry, on the 15th of March, and cutting and wounding her on the head, the left side of her face, and left hand, with intent to maim and disable her—2nd COUNT, stating her intent to be to do her some grievous bodily harm.

BRIDGET SANTRY . I am the wife of Dennis Santry, and live at Rother
hithe, in the same house as the prisoner, and Margaret Mulchannaugh. About half-past seven o'clock in the morning of the 15th of March I was lying on my bed—I heard the prisoner outside at the foot of the stairs, calling me by an expression not fit to mention—in the course of ten mi
nutes I heard her again addressing me with the same kind of expression as before—I went down stairs, and knocked at her door, and told her I wanted to speak to her—the second time I spoke she opened the door, and let me in—I told her she deserved a good hiding for her filthy language to me—she told me to hit her—I said I did not feel myself able to do it, but if I was, she deserved it for her abuse to me—she took bold of my hair with her left hand, took her right hand from behind her back, and I felt her stab me on the left side of my head with a knife, but I did not see the knife till after Mrs. Mulcbannaugh came up and took it out of her hand—I was standing up at the time—directly I saw the blood over me, I got so weak I fell down directly—I had two wounds and a scratch—I put up my left hand in my defence, and it cut through my fingers—I felt pain from the cuts, and was very unwell indeed—I was attended by a surgeon for ten days—the blood-vessel then burst out again, and I sent for the doctor, who is attending me still.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Who went down stairs with you to the prisoner's room? A. No one—I am sure of that—her husband was up stairs in my room, and my husband, and Mrs. Mulchannaugh also—we had half a pint of gin between five of us—it was half-past seven o'clock in the morning—I had not been at work—I was on my bed—I got up when the prisoner came to abuse me—she opened her room door to me the second time I knocked—she was alone in her room—she did not receive any injury in the scuffle, that I know of—she had none from me—there was no one but me there—I saw no blood on her—I have had no money from her or her husband about this, but the husband when I first came to the house, warned me not to give her any rent—I have had a sovereign from him since this, and gave it to the surgeon—he has promised me another sove
reign—this was the prisoner's house—I was a lodger—she was not chop
ping wood in her room, that I saw—there was none thrown at her—the policeman came in about half an hour.

MARGARET MULCHANNAUGH . I am the wife of John Mulchannangh and lodged in the house. On the morning of the 15th of March, I heard the prosecutrix scream out—I went to her—she was standing in the pri
soner's room—the prisoner had got hold of her hair by her left hand, and had a carving knife in her right hand—I saw her stab the prosecutrix in the left side of the head, before I had power to take the knife from her—I saw blood come from the prosecutrix—I took the knife from the prisoner and chucked it inside the fender—I had heard the prisoner come to the foot of the stairs, and abuse the prosecutrix as she lay on her bed.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been out that morning? A. Yes, be
tween seven and eight o'clock, for half-a-pint of gin, which we drank in the prosecutrix's room with her husband and the prisoner's husband—the prisoner was below in her own room—I did not hear the prosecutrix say any thing to the prisoner—the policeman came a few minutes after the deed was committed—I cannot say what space it was.

JOHN LONG . I am a policeman. Between seven and eight o'clock in the morning of the 15th of March, I was called into the prisoner's house, and took her into custody—her husband gave me this knife—(producing it)—I asked the prisoner how she came to do it—she said both the witness and the prosecutrix rushed in upon her—that the knife laid on the table, and she laid hold of it to save herself.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you desire the prisoner to wipe her face before taking her to the station house? A. No; but she was bleeding from the forehead—she has the mark now—I did not observe any poker in the room, or any pieces of wood—her face was streaming down with blood—my body must have seen it.

WILLIAM MURDOCK . I am a surgeon, and live in Rotherhithe-street I was called in to see the prosecutrix on the morning of the 15th of March—I found her seated in a corner of the room, her face covered with blood, and her hair dishevelled, falling over her face, clotted with blood—she had fainted from loss of blood, and was then recovering—I found two cuts and a scratch on the left side of her head, a cat on her face, and a cut between the first and second finger of the left hand—they were simple cut wounds—I did not consider them dangerous—they might have been inflicted with this knife—I see a mark on the blade near the handle, which I believe to be blood—I have attended her ever since—she was confined to her bed nine or ten days—she is very near recovery now—there is a wound not quite healed.

MARGARET MULCHANNAUGH
re-examined. That is the knife I took out of the prisoner's hands.
NOT GUILTY .

1454.
JAMES SOMERVTLLE was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Walmsley and others, on the 4 the of April, and stealing therein 1 snuff-box, value 36s., their property.

JOSEPH BRIDGE . I am shopman to George Walmsley and two other, in High-street, Borough, in the parish of St. George the Martyr, South-work. On the afternoon of the 4th of April, I was in the shop—I heard the window crack, turned towards it, and saw the prisoner's hand inside the window—he took a silver snuff-box out, and went by the window with it—I went out, secured him with it in his hand, and gave him in charge.
MICHAEL MANNING (police-constable M 173.) I took the prisoner into custody with the box in his hand, and the ticket attached to it.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1455.
DAVID FITZGERALD was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Speller, on the 10th of March, at Christ Church, Surrey, and stealing therein, 1 tea-caddy, value 12s.; 1 work-box, value 8s.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s. 6d.; 1 table-cover, value 10s.; and 5lbs. weight of beef, value 3s., his property.

WILLIAM SPELLER . I am an iron-plate worker, and live in York
place, Christ Church, Surrey—I rent the whole house. About a quarter to eight o'clock on the night of the 10th of March, in consequence of information, I went into Thorough-street, which is about one hundred and fifty yards from my house, and saw the prisoner and a lad about fourteen yean old—the prisoner passed me with some articles—I found nobody further on and returned, and then found the prisoner kneeling down—I nearly stepped on him—I looked over his shoulder—he asked me what I was looking at—I said, "Nothing particular"—he said, "You can go on"—I said, "I know that," and as he rose up I collared him, and told him I thought he had something belonging to me—I brought him towards the gas-light, and saw the tea-caddy and work-box shine through the hand
kerchief—I afterwards found the table cover in William-street, in the road—I gave him in charge.

HARRIET SPELLER . I am the prosecutor's wife. On the night of the 10th of March, I heard a noise in the front-parlour, like the rattling of plates' and dishes—I had noticed the window between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, it was then down—I went into the parlour on bearing. the noise, and found the window and one blind open, and missed from the table a piece of beef, a tea-caddy, a work-box, a table-cloth, and a table-cover—I had fastened the blinds and shut the window down that day, and they remained so till I heard the noise—it would require a light to see into the parlour at eight o'clock—I took a candle with me—there was the appearance of a candle having been on the table, and a lucifer match, and a smell of sulphur.

RICHARD SENIOR . I am a plumber, and live in Lesson Grove. I was spending the evening at Speller's—he brought the prisoner to the house and gave him into my charge, with the work-box and tea-caddy tied in ft handkerchief—he threw them down at my feet—I took them up and gave them to the constable—I had gone to the house about five o'clock, and the window was down then.

ROBERT TURTLB (police-constable M 56.) On the night of the 10th of March, I was called to the house, and received charge of the prisoner with the things—I found a box of lucifers in his pocket, and Mrs. Speller gave me one partly burnt, off the table.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had only come out of the country on Saturday evening—I had spent the Sunday with a friend—as I came home I saw the smallest box lying down in the middle of Thurlow-street, and about six yards from it was the work-box—I tied them in my handkerchief, and the gentleman came up and took me.

GUILTY . * Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1456.
ELIZABETH HAWES was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, at Camberwell, 1 box, value 1d.; 4 sovereigns, 3 half-sovereigns. 2 dollars, and 2s.; the goods and monies of
Flavius Josephus Hudson, her master, in his dwelling-house.

FLAVIUS JOSEPHUS HUDSON . I am a tea-dealer and grocer, and live in High-street, Peckham, in the parish of Camberwell. On Saturday, the 23rd of March, the prisoner came into my service—on the 27th I sent her out, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, on an errand—she did not return—she was apprehended on the Friday following—I searched my bed. room, as she did not return, and missed three sovereigns, three half-sovereigns, two dollars, and two old shillings, out of the looking-glass drawer—three of the sovereigns were in a small box—the drawer was locked, and I found it still locked.
Prisoner. The drawer was not locked.

PETER WALLIS (police-constable E 72.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody, on the 29th of March, in Vine-court, Tooley-street—I told her the charge—she denied it—I asked if she had any of the property about her person—she said she had not, but that she had part of it stolen from her by a young man, and the remainder she had spent—I found a box on her, which the prosecutor swears to—she had several new clothes on—her clothes were given to me at a house she had taken refuge in—there is a ring and necklace in the bundle.

SARAH EVEREST . I am the wife of David Everest, and live at the station-house, in Lock's-fields. I searched the prisoner, when she was brought to the station-house, and found on her this salve-box, a ring, and a necklace on her neck, which I delivered to the policeman—I asked her what she was charged with—she said robbing her master of six sovereigns, and some silver, but she had not taken more than 4l. 10s.—I asked what she did with it—she said she had spent some, and got drunk, and was robbed of some of it.

FLAVIUS JOSEPH HUDSON
re-examined. This salve-box I can identify as being the one the sovereigns were in—I am quite sure of it, by a parti
cular mark.

GUILTY . * Aged 17—
Transported for Ten Years.

1457.
JOHN BARLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 3 metal cocks, value 5s., the goods of
George Frederick Epstein, his master; to which be pleaded

GUILTY —
Confined Three Months.

1458.
JAMES BELL was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of De
cember, 5 handkerchiefs, value 22s., and 6 yards of lawn, value 10s., the goods of
Martin Atkinson, his master; and
JEMIMA BELL
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

MARTIN ATKINSON . I keep a linen-drapery warehouse, in the West
minster-road. James Bell had been in my service for about eight months, up to March last, and I had known him for some years—I had some sus
picion, and directed a shopman to watch him—on the evening of the 7th of March my shopman communicated something to me, and the prisoner was called back, as he was about leaving my premises—he followed me into my

counting-house—I said to him, "Give me back my property"—he pulled a piece of huckaback out of his pocket, and gave it to me—it was my pro
perty—he said, "I hope you will for give roe, sir, for the sake of my family, and if you will allow me to go home, I will return to-morrow morning, and then do what you like"—I gave him into custody—I have since seen five black silk handkerchiefs, and a piece of lawn, which are mine—these are them—(examining them)—I had missed the handkerchiefs from my shop, and made an outcry about them—I was present at the examination of the pri
soners, they made a statement which was taken down, and as I was leaving the Court, they went up to sign it—this signature to this examination is the hand-writing of James Bell—I do not know the hand-writing of the other prisoner, who is his daughter.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe this man has been in much better life than he is now? A. He was in business for himself about thirteen years back—he has a wife, and I think four children—when he came first to me he had 25s. a-week, as I had younger hands, who took more money than he did, I intimated that he might leave me, but at be said he wished I would keep him till the turn of the year, I said I would give him 20s. a-week, which I did—he boarded in my house.

GEORGE WORLEY . I am in the service of Messrs. Walmsley, pawn-brokers. I produce five handkerchiefs and the lawn, which were pawned on the 19th and 22nd of December, I believe, by the prisoner Jemima Bell.

ROBERT OVENDEN (police-constable L 90.) I attended the examination of the prisoners—I saw them sign this examination—(read)—"Jemima Bell says, I remember pledging the black silk handkerchiefs; my father gave them to me, and told me to pledge them. The man says, My daughter acted under my direction."

JAMES BELL—
GUILTY . Aged 54.

JEMIMA BELL—
NOT GUILTY .

1459.
JAMES BELL was again indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of January, 1 table-cloth, value 4s., the goods of
Martin Atkinson, his master; and
SARAH BELL
, for feloniously receiving the same, well bowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
GEORGE THOMPSON . I am shopman to Mr. Russell, a pawnbroker, in Old Kent-road. I produce a table-cloth pawned, on the 4th of January, by Sarah Bell.
MARTIN ATKINSON . This table-cloth is mine—it was never sold to James Bell.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARXSON. Q. You cannot say that it may not have been sold? A. No, nor when it was missed.
ROBERT OVENDON . I saw Sarah Bell sign this deposition—(read)—"Sarah Bell says, I pledged the table-cloth; my father gave it me to pledge. James Bell says, My daughter acted under my direction."

JAMES BELL—
GUILTY . Aged 54.—
Transported for Seven Years.

SARAH BELL—
NOT GUILTY .

1460.
WILLIAM EVANS was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of March, 1/4lb. weight of tea, value 1s.; and 1 brush, value 3s.; the goods of
Henry Craven, his master.
HENRY CRAVEN . I am a grocer, and live in Wandsworth-road The,

prisoner was my shopman—I suspected he was robbing me, and in the beginning of March I marked some money, and gave it to a neighbour to bring to my shop—the prisoner was searched for a shilling, and this tea was found on him, on the morning of the 12th of March—I have tea which exactly resembles this, and the paper it is in exactly resembles mine, but I could not say that I had lost any tea—this brush is mine—it was found in the prisoner's box.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Where was the box? A. Up in his bed-room—it was locked—the key was taken from him by the officer—it is a horse-brush, but it will brush clothes—I never knew him to brush his clothes up stairs—he generally came down into the kitchen to do that—he had been in my service about twelve months.
JAMES WILLIAM BURRIDGE (police-constable V 160.) I was called in—I found a shilling on the prisoner, and this tea and this brush in his box.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he give you the key of his box? A. Yes—he said nothing about the brush or the tea.
NOT GUILTY .

1461.
WILLIAM EVANS was again indicted
for embezzlement.

HENRY CRAVEN . I live in Britannia-place, Wands worth road. On the 11th of March, I marked three shillings, and gave them to Mr. Young, a draper close by, to bring to my shop at half past seven o'clock the next morning, and in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after Mr. Young was gone, I went to the till, and there was only one of the marked shillings in it—this is one of the shillings—(examining one.)

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How is it marked? A. In three places with small dots made with a brad-awl—if the prisoner had to give change for any thing, be gave it out of the till—he had no right to give change out of his own money, and I never knew him to do it—in my absence if he could not get change from the till, he might give change from his pocket, but on that morning there was no larger money in the till then shillings—I usually take the money out of the till at night—I cannot tell how many customers had been there—there were five or six shillings be
side the marked shilling—there is 14s. due to him for two weeks' wages—I boarded him.

CHARLES YOUNG . On the 11th of March, the prosecutor delivered me three shillings, which were all marked, and the next morning about half-past seven o'clock, I laid out two of them at his shop—I gave them to the prisoner—they were both marked alike—this is one of the shillings.

Cross-examined. Q. What became of the other shilling? A. I have left it at home—I gave the prosecutor a shilling for it—I had left the pro
secutor's shop before the policeman was called in—there was one woman inthe shop when I was there—I purchased a piece, of bacon.
JAMES WILLIAM BURRIDGE (police-constable V 160.) I searched the prisoner, and found the tea—this shilling he produced himself, I believe from his coat pocket.

Cross-examined. Q. How many shillings had he? A. Three, and one half-crown, besides this shilling—he took them all out, and his master looked over them, and found the marked shilling among them—this is it—he made no difficulty in producing his money.
(The prisoner received a goad character.)

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

1462.
ANN M'DERMOT was indicted
for, that one
Pamela Elizabeth Hall, on the 13th of November, did steal 2 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 3 sixpences, the monies of
James Fagg; and that the said Ann M'Dermot did feloniously and maliciously incite, mote, procure, counsel, hire and command the said Pamela Elisabeth Hall the felony aforesaid to do and commit; against the Statute, &c.

PAMELA ELIZABETH HALL . I was fourteen yean old on the 16th of last October, and live with my grandmother, Mrs. Fagg, at No. 9, Ber
mondsey-street. I was living with her in November last—the prisoner. had at one time lodged in my grandmother's house—I have taken half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences belonging to my grandmother a great many times by desire of the prisoner—in November I took two half-crowns, six shillings, and three sixpences, by her desire—I was in the prisoner's house when she desired me to do it—I went to her house be
cause she told me I was to go there—great part of the money I took was spent in drink, and the other part bought furniture—I bought some at Mr. Smith's at Crucifix-lane, and at Snow's-fields—I bought some chain and some fire-irons with the money I took from my grandmother, and they were taken to the prisoner's house—the prisoner was with me when. I bought some of the things, and her daughter was with me when I bought some of them—the prisoner told me that John Hubbard was to marry me—the chain that were produced from Mr. Warton's, the pawnbroker, were the same that were bought at Mr. Smith's—some china cups and saucers were bought with my grandmother's money, the prisoner's daughter went with me to buy them—I used frequently to go to the prisoner I in the after-noon, and stop all the afternoon—I slept there two nights—I do not recol
lect when I told my grandmother of taking the money, but I did tell her—I took the money because the prisoner told me—she told me several times to do it before I did it.

Prisoner. I was forty-three miles down in Kent, and my daughter and John Hubbard, and this girl, kept company for two years, and they had the house to do as they pleased. Witness. She was not in the country, she was at home in November—I did not keep company with her daugh
ter above nine months—I knew John Hubbard before I knew her—the prisoner told me to do this a great many times before I did it—a coat was bought with a sovereign that I took from my grandmother, and the prisoner gave me a bad sovereign to put in its place—I did not go to buy the coat—there had been 2s. paid off it, and I paid 16s. at the prisoner's desire, out of the sovereign—the rest of the sovereign was spent in gin and ale at the prisoner's house the same night—the prisoner forced me to drink some.

Prisoner. You know you said you would come to my place when you liked—you knew John Hubbard before you knew me—he said he thought more of my daughter than of you, and then you stated this about the so
vereign, and said any thing was your property. Witness. John Hubbard never had any thing to say to her daughter that I know of—what I have said is the truth.

ANN FAGG . I am the wife of James Fagg of Bermondsey-street, a butcher. Pamela Elizabeth Hall was born in my house, find lived with me, except when she went on a visit to my son—the prisoner lodged in my house, and left me on the 16th of October last—both before and after she

was gone, I missed money—I missed money in November, but it is im
possible to say to what amount—Hall was in the shop, and took money the same as I did—she behaved with the greatest propriety before the pri
soner came, and was liked by every neighbour—I think it is about a month or five weeks ago that Hall first told me about taking any money—I believe I have lost more than 20l., but Hall lives with me still, and always shall—I will forgive her.

Prisoner. If you lost money, where are Mary Sampson's fine dresses which the girl confessed she bought? Witness. I know her, she is rather older than ray granddaughter—I know John Hubbard—I heard that he and Hall kept company, but I never saw them together—I believe his pa
rents are hard-working people.

THOMAS SMITH . I am a broker, and live in Crucifix-lane, Snow's-fields. In November Hall came to my shop—the prisoner's daughter had come then with her, and the prisoner herself had come with her—Hall bought some fire-irons of me, and to my best recollection, the prisoner's daughter was with her then—I had a table, the prisoner's daughter came for it, and asked the price of it, Hall then came with her, and then the prisoner came with Hall, and looked at it—they did not buy it—the prisoner came with Hall to buy a saucepan, and Hall paid for it—Hall paid for some chain and some pictures.

Prisoner. I never bought a saucepan of you in my life—it was my hus
band who was after the table a long while—I said it was not worth the money. Witness. At the time you dealt for the saucepan, a surgeon came by, who you said had saved your life.
EDWARD BENNETT . I am in the employ of Mr. Walton, a pawnbroker, I have two chairs, half a dozen cups and saucers, and two dishes which were pawned by the prisoner.

PAMELA ELIZABETH HALL
re-examined. I paid for thesechairs.
Prisoner. I pawned the chairs, the cups and saucers, and dishes—my daughter said they were bought with my husband's club-money.

JOHN KINSEY . I am an officer of the Borough. On the night of the 8th of March, I went to the prisoner's house in Stoney-lane—I saw there was a light in the room—the shutters were closed—I knocked at the door—the prisoner said, "Who is there?"—I said, "A friend, open the door"—I knocked again, and said, "Is Mrs. M'Dermot at home?"—the pri
soner said, "No, she is not"—I wrenched the shutters open, and was in the act of lifting the window, when the prisoner said, "Put the window down, I will open the door," which she did—I then went in and found this box on the mantel-piece, with the duplicates of some of the property in it—I apprehended her.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite falsely sworn against—it is all jealousy—I told this girl's grandmother that she was seen with a deal of money.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1463.
GEORGE TUCKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of March, 1 counterpane, value 6s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 1s. 6d., 1 apron, value 19d.; and 1 flannel shirt, value 19d.; the goods of
Henry Chubb.

HENRY CHUBB . I live at Stockwell, the prisoner lodged at my house. On the 12th of March I missed a counterpane, and the other articles—some of them had been in his room—these are them—(examining them.)

MARK BREAKSPEAR (police-constable E 30.) On the 12th of March I saw the prisoner with a bundle—I asked what he had got—he said a few things of his own—I found in this apron a shirt and breeches—he said he did not steal them, but took them from his lodging—the counterpane had been pawned.
Prisoner's Defence. I was out of work and in great distress.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1464.
THOMAS CONNOR,
GEORGE BRATT,
JAMES SANDS , and
HENRY CHURCHILL , were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March, 150lbs. weight of lead, value 1l. 5s. the goods of
Daniel Smith, and fixed to a certain building.

HENRY CAVELL . I am a plasterer's labourer. I live opposite Mr. Daniel Smith's warehouse, which is in Woolpack-yard, Kent-street—on the 12th of March, about half-past eleven o'clock in the evening, I was look
ing out of window, and there were some men below—at twelve o'clock some man went from the bottom room of the house I was in, to the end of the court, and some person went past the court—the man who went from the house came back again, and said, "Now then," and immediately something was thrown off the roof of the warehouse—it was white, and I thought it was a dead body rolled up in a sheet—I called Thomas Dennead to look at it—he got out of bed, in the room where I was, and looked at it—there were then two men on the roof of the warehouse—I saw them, but did not know who they were—after that I saw one man drop from the top of the warehouse, down by the water-closet—he came straight across, and to the room I was in—it was Connor—we asked him what it was he threw off the warehouse—he said about 2 cwt of lead—be then borrowed the key of the young man I was stopping with, and went down stairs to the bottom room of the house I was in.

THOMAS DENNEAD . I live in the same room with Cavell—he called me, I got out of bed, and saw two men crossing the road with the lead, and saw two men on the roof—I saw them come down by the spout, and jump on the water-closet—the lead was brought into the room under mine—Sands was one of the men who brought it, and I think that Bratt was the other, but he has a different dress on now—Bratt and Sands live in a room in the next court—I had known them before—Connor then came to me and borrowed the key—he said he turned down about 2 cwt of lead—I saw lead the next morning under a table in Connor's room.

JANE JOHNSON . I lodge at the house in Woolpack-yard. At two o'clock, on Wednesday, the 13th of March, I went into Connor's room for a light—I saw some lead partly up the chimney, and part in the fire-place—it was black, and I asked if it was leather—Connor said, "Yes"—there was a frying pan under the grate, and the melted lead fell into the pan.
CHARLES BURRIDGE (police-constable M 77.) I went into Connor's room on that Wednesday, and apprehended him with Bratt and Sands—they were lying on the bed—I found no lead there.
JOHN BLAZER (police-constable M 145.) I went to Connor's room, and found a small piece of lead on the table, and some melted lead in the fire-place.
DANIEL SMITH . This was my warehouse, and was stripped off its
lead—I had seen it all safe in the afternoon, previous to its being taken—I lost about forty square feet of lead from the front of the warehouse.

JURY to THOMAS DENNEAD. Q. Can you speak to Sands positively? A. Yes, he was one who picked up the lead—I was about thirty yards from him—Connor and Churchill were on the top of the roof and came down by the water-closet—I think Brett was one who picked up the lead.
Connor's Defence, The persons who have come against me have all sworn falsely—the first witness goes about begging with a soldier's jacket on—the other witnesses are the same.
Sands Defence. I know no more about it than a child.
Churchill's Defence. I was not near the place.

CONNOR—
GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Transported for Seven Years.

SANDS—
GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined Six Months.

BRATT AND CHURCHILL—
NOT GUILTY .

1465.
GEORGE JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of March, 1 1/4 pint of brandy, value 5s. 6d., 11/2 pint of gin, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Coulton, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY —
Confined One Month.

1466.
LOUISA FERGUSON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. BODKIN and DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

ANN CHESNET . I am the wife of Joseph Chesney, a stationer in Ber
mondsey-street On the morning of the 3rd of March the prisoner came in for a "Paul Pry," which came to 3d.—she gave me 2d. for it—I said I could not let her have it—she said she had been in the habit of having it every week for that—I said it had been raised to 3d. for three months, but perhaps she meant the "Town"—she then said, "Let me have the "Town"—I gave her a "Town," which is 2d.—she gave me a sixpence, and I gave her 4d. change—I laid the sixpence on a shelf behind me—after she was gone I looked at it, and thought it was a bad one—I showed it to my daughter—I then put it by itself in a purse, which I have now in my pocket, and threw it into the till—it remained there till the prisoner came—on the 17th of March, when my daughter was in the shop, the pri
soner came in, I heard her voice—I came into the shop, and then she wanted a "Paul Pry" for 2d.—I told her she could not have it for that—she had the "Town" again, and offered a bad sixpence to my daughter, who did not give her change, but kept the sixpence in her hand, and showed it to me—I told the prisoner it was bad, and that she had passed one to me that very day fortnight—she said no, she had not been in the shop before—my husband sent for the policeman, and gave him the two sixpences.

LOUISA CHESNEY . I am the prosecutrix's daughter. On Sunday, the 17th of March, the prisoner came to my mother's shop—she asked for a twopenny "Paul Pry"—I told her it was 3d.—she then changed to the "Town," and offered me a counterfeit sixpence—my mother came in, and the sixpence was detained—I marked it, and gave it to the policeman.
ROBERT ROSOMAN (police-constable M 158.) I was called in on the 17th of March—I took the prisoner, and received these two sixpences.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These are both counterfeit.
Prisoner. I acknowledge the sixpence was bad; but I was driven to it by distress asked a young man to lend me a shilling, and he gave me the sixpence to pass—I had not been there before.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Year.

1467.
JOHN HOLBROOK was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JOSEPH IZOD . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Blackman-street, in the Borough. On the 28th of March the prisoner came to my shop for half a pound of bacon—it came to 4d.—he gave me a half-crown, which was bad—I told him so, I kept it, and gave it to the officer.

THOMAS READY . On the 29th of March, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came to my shop and bought an article, which came to 6d.—he gave me a half-crown—I suspected it was bad, and kept it by itself—I gave him two shillings change, and he left—the policeman came soon afterwards—I marked the half-crown, and gave it him.

Prisoner. I called for half a pound of boiled beef. Witness. Yes, and I had none—then you had roast beef—you were in the shop about five minutes—another man came in while you were there, who I considered was one of your quality—he tried to attract my attention—I could swear to you.
JOHN BLAZER . I am an officer. I went to Mr. Izod's on the 30th of March—he gave me this half-crown, which I produce.
GEORGB HAVILL (police-sergeant M 2.) Mr. Ready gave me this half-crown.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These half-crowns are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1468.
LAWRENCE LEE was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of March, 1 ass, price 1l., the property of
John Bradfield; and 1 ass, price 1l.; the property of
Samuel Smith.

JOHN BRADFIELD . I live at Wimbledon. On the morning of the 23rd of March, my boy turned my donkey out, it was afterwards missing, and is worth 1l. 1s.—Samuel Smith, my son-in-law, also lost his donkey. I saw them both at Deptford.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When had you seen it safe? A. On the night before—I saw it again on the Tuesday week following.
HENRY BRADFIELD . I am the prosecutor's son. I turned out a male donkey on Wimbledon-common, on the Saturday morning—it was missed that day—I saw it afterwards at the Fountain, at Deptford.

THOMAS HORRICK . I am a chair-bottomer. On Saturday evening, the 30th of March, Christopher Jones came, and asked me to buy a donkey—he wanted 28s. for it—I said it was too much—he said he had another in the yard—I said I would look at that—he brought in another, and the prisoner came in with him—I asked the price of that—the prisoner said, 26s.—I said it was too much, and I offered two sovereigns for the two—they would not take it—I offered two guineas—they would not take it—they went away, and in ten minutes came back, and Jones said, if I would stand beer-money I should have them—I said, "No"—they said I should have them—I counted the money on the table—Jones took it up, and he said to the prisoner, "You know what I have to give you for yours."
Cross-examined. Q. Have you found Jones since? A. No—I believe he has been looked after, but he is out of the way.

EDWARD PALMER . I am a police-constable. I went to apprehend the prisoner—he said, "You want me, Mr. Palmer, I will go with you, but am innocent of the case—Smith gave me the donkeys, and took them to the Fountain, but Smith is not here."

ABRAHAM HOWELL . I saw two men driving three donkeys on Wim
bledon-common, on the 23rd, but I cannot swear the prisoner was one.
NOT GUILTY .

1469.
EDWARD BURNS and
WILLIAM TILLEY were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April, 1 pair of half-boots, value 4s., the goods of
John Christopher Woollacot and another; to which Burns pleaded

GUILTY . * Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

ELIZABETH GOLDING . I live nearly opposite Mr. Woollacot in Mint-street, Borough. I saw the two prisoners there on the 10th of April, about a quarter before ten o'clock at night—they went into the shop—I saw Bums give a snatch, and the boots fell down—they came out, and Burns returned, and took the boots—they went on towards St. George's church.

WILLIAM HOWLETT . I am in the service of John Christopher Woolla
cot and another. I was told of this, and missed a pair of half-boots—I went out and pursued Burns, who had got the boots on him.
WILLIAM HUMPHREYS . I am a policeman. I saw the prisoner in company near the window, peeping and looking in several times—I saw Burns snatch the boots.
Tilley's Defence. I had got 100 yards from the place before the robbery was committed, and then Bums ran up to me, and said, "Here they are"—I know nothing about the robbery.

TILLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1470.
JOHN NICHOLLS was indicted
for b—g—y.
NOT GUILTY .
